The musical excerpt displayed in the poster ( 10) comprises the final three measures of Weill's holograph pre-rehearsal score of the "Ballade vom angenehmen Leben," which he had sent UE in 1928 for the purpose of preparing rehearsal and performance materials. Only someone with access to UE's archives could have made this contribution to Weill's defamation. His identity remains a mystery. 80

An event which may have left Weill with what Schlee called "a very bad impression" was the disappearance, in 1933, of a parcel containing virtually all of Weill's unpublished early works, including, most likely, the op. 5 Divertimento, the orchestral cycle of Rilke's Stundenbuch, Recordare, Zaubernacht, and the symphonic Fantasia, Passacaglia, und Hymnus. In 1932 Weill had lent these and other scores to musicologist Walter Fleischer, who was working on a volume about the composer to follow one on Stravinsky. Fleischer vividly recalled the circumstances: "I was in Italy, and knowing nothing of Weill's whereabouts after March 1933, I mailed the package of scores to the Berlin office of Universal Edition, in care of Alfred Schlee. In December 1933, when I saw Weill again at a performance of Mahagonny in Rome, I told him what I'd done with his manuscripts. Although he expressed no surprise at the disappearance of the package, at the mention of Schlee's name, Weill silently wagged his right forefinger twice: left-right, left-right." 81

The only essay published after World War II by the once prolific Schlee was a report to Modern Music, printed in the April 1946 issue under the title "Vienna Since the Anschluss." 82 Schlee opened with a brief disclaimer explaining why he hadn't written anything for the journal in a decade:

When your request for an article reached me, I was deeply affected. Since my last review, many years had passed and even when I saw that in print, I knew it was no longer possible to write for you. I could not dare then really to express my thoughts, and if I wrote between the lines, how could you, living in a country where every man's right to freedom of expression is taken for granted, understand?

. . . I wrote nothing for publication thereafter.

Characterizing the period from 1934 to 1938 as one of "hopeless lethargy," Schlee says almost nothing, despite the title of his contribution, about the "seven years of trumpets and concentration camps" since the Anschluss. Noting that Berg, Webern, and Hauer had been "neither honored nor oppressed," but rather "treated with derision," Schlee thanked the "alien nations that supported all those whom the brutal northern invader drove out of their country," including Schoenberg and Krenek. Schlee devotes the remainder of his brief essay to an emotional account of the "tragedy" of Anton von Webern, who "did not survive to enjoy his destined rehabilitation after so many injustices":

It is a tragedy for us too, for we need his counsel and his wisdom. I can speak of this great and heartwarming musician only with the humblest reverence. His modest demeanor cloaked an unbelievable knowledge and goodness. He led a life dedicated entirely to music.

. . . . He ran the risk of being forced into factory labor. I was able to get him a position with the Universal Edition, where he was sheltered by the excuse of essential work. 83

Schlee's poetic portrayal of the martyred Webern seems to have been calculated to discourage doubts about any unresolved discords still reverberating from Schoenberg's anguished and unanswered question put to his former student in June 1937: "Is it true that you have become a supporter, or even a member of the Nazi Party?" 84 (Although there is no evidence that Webern ever joined the party, virtually everyone in his immediate family did, with his son Peter, who was killed in the war, and one of his sons-in-law particularly rabid partisans. Until recently, most biographers and critics have accepted the testimony of Webern's daughter, Amalie Waller: "The occupation of Austria by Hitler was a terrific blow for my father. Not only was his music banned and outlawed because it belonged to the category of 'degenerate art,' but all doors and gates were barred for the conductor and teacher Webern." 85 Peter Stadlen recalled an exchange with Webern later that same year, when he was working intensively with the composer in preparation for the premiere of his Piano Variations:

One day we went through the Prater. Suddenly he said: "If the Nazis come, I will go to Goebbels and tell him that he is misinformed and that twelve-tone music is not Kultur-Bolschewismus. "Of that you will perhaps persuade him, Herr Doktor," I replied, "but could you ever persuade him that Schoenberg is not a Jew?" "No," said Webern, "but that he is nevertheless a decent man!" 86

By recounting the hardships which the "other-worldly" bystander Webern had endured during and immediately after the war at the hands of both its perpetrators and, inadvertently, its victors, his friend and publisher Schlee was still looking "beyond the present" to "a time afterwards" and laying the groundwork for the heroicization of the "anständiger Mensch" ("decent man") Webern. But as the disturbing "trotzdem" ("nevertheless") of Webern's own case, his enthusiastic embrace of Hitler and National Socialist ideology, has gradually and painfully been revealed in subsequent decades, Schlee's messianic mythology has collapsed into willful historical fiction. A more accurate, and necessarily less sympathetic, portrait suggests a metaphor more apt than Schlee's biblical one. Webern had indeed suffered, but as a tragic Greek hero, whose fatal flaw was an inability or unwillingness to integrate or reconcile his life and art. Absent evidence to corroborate the testimony of Webern's daughter that the occupation of Austria by Hitler was a terrific blow for her father or Robert Craft's claims that the Nazis banned his music, burned his writings, and forbade him all activity, Webern's purported persecution for his aesthetic allegiance to twelve-tone composition now must also be doubted. 87 The wartime neglect of his music can no longer believably be ascribed to official governmental proscription or censorship on racial, political, or aesthetic grounds.

Although his music had been performed only rarely before the National Socialists came to power, Webern's portrayal as a "suppressed" composer of "subversive" music became a crucial component of post-war modernist strategies to turn away from a corrupt recent past and claim for serialism the highest moral ground, as the only alternative truly responsive to the horrors of the recent past. 88 However, with Webern as standard bearer, post-war serialists, asserted Hans Werner Henze, actually sought to restore music to "a state of purity as if nothing had happened; as if there were no class struggle, no imperialism, no wars, as if society were in order; as though everything were as untouched as blades of grass high in the Alps." 89 "It was precisely its utopian (its 'scientific') aspect, as well as the myth of its political suppression," Richard Taruskin has observed, "that facilitated serialism's seeming natural selection as the neomodernist lingua franca from out of the ashes of the Second World War." 90 Because the post-war construction of a new ethical framework for music after Auschwitz depended on the belief of the historical imperative and aesthetic superiority of serialism, the depoliticization of modern music required the depoliticization of Anton Webern.

By detaching the discovery which was supposed to have assured the supremacy of German music for a hundred years from its ideological origins and socio-political ramifications, Schlee posited, already in 1946, a key component in what would become the dominant historical narrative of twentieth-century music. (Its prevalence and longevity is evinced in so recent a survey as Arnold Whittall's Musical Composition in the Twentieth Century [1999], which still glosses Webern's politics and wartime conduct as merely "right-wing sympathies" and then dismisses them as irrelevant because "the music's qualities transcend rather than helplessly implement its ideological context.") 91 Thus, years before Pierre Boulez, one of UE's first post-war recruits, announced that "Schoenberg Is Dead" and admonished the musical world not "to forget that a certain Webern also labored," Schlee had anointed his friend as the only reliable guide into "the Promised Land," the rightful interpreter of "the sacred Tablets of Law." 92

When Alfred Kalmus decided to remain in London after the war, Schlee took over operations in Vienna. From that strategic base, he quickly claimed the role of chief architect of its high modernist edifice, built substantially on the foundations of the already proliferating martyrology of Webern. 93 Schlee recruited a youthful roster of composers rivaling Hertzka's, but with few of the eclectics, dissenters, and populists who had balanced the Second Viennese School within UE's catalogue during the interwar period. 94 With Boulez and Stockhausen quickly emerging as its principal spokesmen and, after 1955, the new UE-periodical Die Reihe: Information über serielle Musik serving as its propagandist mouthpiece, what Henze described as "official musical thinking" adopted Webern's procedures as its foundation, "whose maxims the body of lesser mortals now had to put into practice (allowing for seasonal variation) with religious devotion, esprit de corps and slavish obedience"(BFAA, 43). Disillusioned by the confusion of moral and aesthetic criteria which "demanded that every deviation from the officially prescribed rules and regulations be denounced and punished without a moment's delay," Henze came to equate the enforced homogeneity of serial music in the 1950s with lingering fascism in his homeland: "so many people who had had a hand in things were now carrying on as if nothing had happened. . . . With the coming of the first strict serial compositions, the least glimmer of any political spark was finally extinguished in the midst of their creators" (BFAA, 34).

When Henze returned to Darmstadt in 1955 to give a composition class with Boulez and Bruno Maderna, he recalled that "anything that wasn't Webernian was brusquely dismissed" (BFAA, 43). Other than Henze, very few composers managed to resist the imperatives of what was already being called "The Age of Webern." As a consequence of Webern's prime directive that "all art must be constructed according to laws," on both sides of the Atlantic "his scores were pored over in theory and composition classes like Talmudic texts," with disdain heaped on any who resisted. 95 When Boulez dared even to assert that "any musician who has not experienced . . . the necessity for the dodecaphonic languages is useless, for his whole work is irrelevant to the needs of the epoch," dissenters began to speak of a new sort of "tyranny" surrounding Webern's oeuvre. 96 Even the seventy-three year old Stravinsky "came under the spell" and penned a short preface for the second issue of Die Reihe, dedicated exclusively to Webern on the occasion of the tenth anniversary of his death: "We must hail not only this great composer but also a real hero." 97

"There are heroes, and there are composers," quipped Schoenberg in 1944, suggesting that Shostakovich had (unfortunately) allowed politics to influence his compositional style: "Heroes can be composers and vice versa, but you cannot require it." 98 That admonition pertains to music publishers as well. On the occasion of their ninetieth birthdays, Ludwig Strecker (who had outlived his brother Willy by 20 years) and Alfred Schlee were both duly feted on a heroic scale. In honor of Strecker, Schott published a 425-page Festschrift für einen Verleger. Among its 46 distinguished contributors were composers Francaix, Henze, Ligeti, Tippett, not to mention Philipp Jarnach and Werner Egk; musicologists and critics included Hans Heinrich Eggebrecht, Rudolph Stephan, H. H. Stuckenschmidt, and Helmut Federhofer. Carl Orff contributed the opening rhapsody, "Dank an Ludwig Strecker"; Hermann Reutter followed up with an "Hommage á Ludwig Emanuel Strecker." There is, of course, no hint anywhere in the volume of Strecker's own "right-wing sympathies." The Festschrift was edited by the doyen of German musicology, Carl Dahlhaus. 99

Conversely, in 1991, in honor of Schlee's ninetieth birthday, no fewer than 37 UE-composers wrote tribute pieces, which were then played by a string quartet at a celebratory concert. Boulez was the official spokesman for the occasion. "Universal Edition meant for us young composers the Second Viennese School, and we wanted to belong. . . . And suddenly we were standing in line with Schoenberg, Berg, and Webern, with their politics, with their artistic goals," Boulez told Die Zeit. He extolled the virtues of his publisher in terms that now seem rather ambiguous:

Alfred Schlee always had his nose to the wind. . . . Nevertheless, the man is extraordinarily private. He never talks about himself. If you want to know something about him, you have to ask someone else. You can hardly pull anything out of him about what role he played after joining Universal Edition in 1927, most of all, about the time of National Socialism and the war years when he practically saved Anton von Webern. 100

By then, Schlee had, in fact, broken his silence about his pre-1945 years at UE by consenting to be interviewed for a retrospective issue of the Oesterreichische Musikzeitschrift on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of the Anschluss. The brief published excerpt from a "detailed interview" with Lothar Knessl began with a disclaimer that Schlee "did not want to make a contribution concerning his special service in securing the survival of UE." 101 But his comments were almost entirely restricted to the preservation of materials that "would ensure that nothing would happen to put UE into a situation in which reestablishment of its international work at 'a time afterwards' might be rendered impossible." "My immediate concern," he said, "was not dedicated to the present, but to the future, something which has always been in the forefront of my considerations." 102

Such elliptical generalities, of course, beg for precise particulars: What did Schlee do in Berlin on a daily basis from 1933 to 1938, or in Vienna from 1938 to 1945, other than looking beyond the present to preserve UE's future? Was he a double-agent, an apolitical, modernist "mole" in the enemy camp, pretending to answer to Petschull but actually looking out for Kalmus's interests? Why had so prolific a writer, so public a performer, so vociferous an advocate prior to the Anschluss, chosen to remain virtually silent about his activities thereafter? His "legendary privacy" would be maintained even in death, as his demise was not announced, even within UE, until after his burial. Obituaries, cobbled almost exclusively from an official press release belatedly issued by UE, offer no new information to affirm, contradict, or supplement the hazy picture of a modest and largely unsung hero of modern music. 103 Somehow, therefore, it was not a shock to discover that even the obviously well-thumbed folder labelled "Alfred Schlee" among the official files of the Reichsmusikkammer was empty--by the time it was microfilmed. Not even the required application for membership remained between its covers.

When Lotte Lenya returned for the first time to Vienna and Berlin in 1955, after twenty years' absence, she reported to a friend back home: "By now we're used to the rubble, which they clean up religiously and indefatigably. What a determination to get on top again! But you can't find a single Nazi in Germany today. It's as if there weren't any." 104 Apparently not in music publishing, a field in which collective amnesia has conspired to rehabilitate the opportunists, collaborators, and stalwarts alike. The deeds of the Petschulls and Streckers were quickly forgotten, forgiven, or transred, those of the Schlees filtered, blandished, and mythologized--all no less quickly and fully than their "black," "grey," and "white" political and industrial counterparts under the utilitarian policies adopted first by the occupation forces and then Christian-conservative politicians, as they tried to reconstruct Germany and Austria. Despite the difficulty today of disentangling aesthetic and musical issues from ideological, political, racialist, and personal ones, it is imperative that we begin the process of shedding light on the dark side of modern music publishing under the Nazis and its continuing impact on contemporary music. 105 Within those shadows remain many unanswered, and perhaps already unanswerable, questions.

* * *

In 1973 Schott and UE joined forces to found the Wiener Urtext Edition. The two firms also began to serve as each other's agent in various territories, including Germany and Austria. In 1977 they jointly established European American Music Distributors Corporation to represent their catalogues in the United States and Canada. In the 1990s Schott Musik International purchased a 30% minority interest in MUVA, the Swiss holding company for Universal Edition, from Music Sales, Inc., which had, in turn, acquired its shares from Susan Kalmus, one of Alfred Kalmus's two daughters. Currently the managing director of Schott is Dr. Peter Hanser-Strecker, the maternal grandson of Ludwig Strecker, Jr. Also trained as a lawyer, though neither a librettist nor tournament tennis player, Hanser-Strecker has adopted a now-familiar pseudonym when publishing his avocational photographs of such notable Schott composers as Ligeti and Penderecki: "Peter Andersen."



Kim H. Kowalke is Professor of Musicology at the University of Rochester. He is the author or editor of four books, including Kurt Weill in Europe and Speak Low: The Letters of Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya. Current research interests include Whitman settings, Hindemith, Orff, Sondheim, and the American musical theater.

Notes

1. I am grateful to Heidi Owen for research assistance in preparation of this essay; to Tamara Levitz for sharing with me her research on Alfred Schlee and Rudolf von Laban; to David Drew, David Farneth, Ronald Freed, Stephan Harpner, Marion von Hartlieb, Elmar Juchem, Michael Kater, David Monod, Albrecht Riethmüller, Eva Smirzitz, Lys Symonette, and Robert Thompson for answers to specific inquiries; to Universal Edition for its cooperation in granting me access to relevant documents, and to Bruce McClung, Joan Evans, Elizabeth Keagy, and Jean Caruso for their helpful responses to earlier drafts of this essay. A preliminary version of this study was presented at the "Music and Nazism" conference at York University, Toronto, on 15 October 1999. My research was supported with a sabbatical leave from the University of Rochester. Translations from the German are my own, unless otherwise noted.

The surviving correspondence between Weill and Universal Edition (hereafter UE) will soon be on deposit at the Sibley Music Library, University of Rochester; complete sets of photocopies reside at the Weill-Lenya Research Center in New York and the Weill/Lenya Archives in the Music Library of Yale University, New Haven. Letters cited here were consulted at the Weill-Lenya Research Center and are cited by permission of UE and the Kurt Weill Foundation for Music. A volume of selected correspondence, edited by Nils Grosch, will be published by Metzler Verlag in 2001.

2. Translated and quoted by Robert Craft, Stravinsky: Selected Correspondence (New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1985), 3:218. Craft's translation has been silently corrected by removing the extraneous "no" from the phrase, "that no one can regard."

3. Arnold Schoenberg, "The Future of Opera," Style and Idea: Selected Writings of Arnold Schoenberg, ed. Leonard Stein (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1984), 336. Although Adorno's attempts to define the relationship between the "autonomy-," "critical-," and "commodity character" of music were lifelong occupations, a key document is the 1932 essay, "Zur gesellschaftlichen Lage der Musik," ed. Rolf Tiedemann, Gesammelte Schriften (Frankfurt a.M.: Suhrkamp, 1984) 18: 719-77. See also Max Paddison, Adorno's Aesthetics of Music (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1993), 97-107.

4. The formulation here is Arnold Whittall's in Musical Composition in the Twentieth Century (London: Oxford University Press, 1999), 3.

5. Arnold Whittall, Music Since the First World War, 2nd ed. (London: Dent, 1977, 1988), 2-3.

6. Most of the book-length studies of music publishing are anecdotal memoirs. The best of them are Hans W. Heinsheimer's Best Regards to Aida: The Defeats and Victories of a Music Man on Two Continents (New York: Knopf, 1968), Fanfare for Two Pigeons (Garden City, NY: Doubleday, 1952), Menagerie in F Sharp (Garden City, NY: Doubleday, 1947), and Ernst Roth's The Business of Music: Reflections of a Music Publisher (London: Cassell, 1969). An entertaining but almost entirely derivative and frequently unreliable account of the business of publishing "serious music" comprises Chapter 12 of Norman Lebrecht's Who Killed Classical Music?: Maestros, Managers, and Corporate Politics (Secaucus, New Jersey: Carol Publishing, 1977), 322-42. Currently there is no study of serious music publishing comparable in scope to Russell Sanjek, American Popular Music and Its Business, 3 vols. (New York: Oxford University Press, 1988). Doctoral Dissertations in Musicology Online lists as in progress: Lillian Necker, Musikverlage im Dritten Reich (Ph.D. Musicology, Hamburg).

7. Schott Musik International's website is www.schott-music.com.

8. Hans W. Heinsheimer, Best Regards to Aida: The Defeats and Victories of a Music Man on Two Continents (New York: Knopf, 1968), 95.

9. Joseph Goebbels, "Speech for the Düsseldorf Music Festival," trans. Robert P. Morgan, Source Readings in Music History, vol. 7: The Twentieth Century, rev. ed. (New York: W. W. Norton, 1998), 126.

10. Peter Raabe, "Ueber den Musikbetrieb während des Krieges," Zeitschrift für Musik (October 1939): 1030; trans. Michael Meyer in The Politics of Music in the Third Reich (New York: Peter Lang, 1991), 179.

"Das Land der Musik" is reprinted in Entartete Musik, 47; its origins are unidentified both there and in the credited source, Klaus Theweleit, Männerphantasien 2. (Reinbek bei Hamburg: Rowohlt, 1984); it also appears in the English translation by Erica Carter and Chris Turner, Male Fantasies, vol. 2, Male Bodies: Psychoanalyzing the White Terror (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 1989), 411.

11. Alan E. Steinweis, Art, Ideology, and Economics in Nazi Germany: The Reich Chambers of Music, Theater, and the Visual Arts (Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1993), 5, 44-45; hereafter cited by as AIENG, followed by a page reference. Even in Steinweis's invaluable chronicle of the evolution of the Reichsmusikkammer, music publishing receives only passing mention. Neither Schott nor UE, neither its owners nor its employees, appear in Joseph Wulf, Musik im Dritten Reich: Eine Dikumentation (Gütersloh: Sigbert Mohn Verlag, 1963). Music publishers and dealers comprised Division E, the Deutscher Musikalien-Verleger Verein, of the Reichsmusikkammer. In 1938 the Verein was dissolved and reconstituted as the Council of Music Publishers.

12. Facsimiles of "Amtliche Mitteilungen der Reichsmusikkammer" that included lists of "unerwünschte Musik" are reproduced in Entartete Musik: Dokumentation und Kommentar, ed. Albrecht Dümling & Peter Girth (Düsseldorf: dkv, 1993), 67-70

13. On the subject of "Musical Foreign Policy," see Michael Meyer, The Politics of Music in the Third Reich, 142-179 (hereafter referred to as Politics).

14. In Gedruckte Musik: 223 Jahre Musikverlag Schott in Mainz (Mainz: Gutenberg-Museum, 1995), for example, Marlene Hübel's otherwise detailed history of the firm makes only oblique reference to the period of the Third Reich. In "Schott in the Twentieth Century" at www.schott-music.com, the publishing company focuses on its long-term relationship with Stravinsky, Hindemith, and Orff ("reviver of the German musical theatre tradition"). The chronicle concludes: "Ever since, Schott has concentrated on long-term relationships with their authors." The select list includes Werner Egk, Wolfgang Fortner, and Hermann Reutter. See also 200 Jahre B. Schott's Söhne. Historisch-bibliographische Schau in 300 ausgewählten Titeln (Tutzing: Musikantiquariat Hans Schneider, 1970); Der Musikverlag B. Schott's Söhne, Mainz (Mainz: Schott, 1954). With respect to Universal Edition, see Ernst Hilmar and Otto Brusatti, eds., 75 Jahre Universal Edition (1901-1976) (Vienna: Universal Edition, 1976); Rudolf Stephan, "Ein Blick auf die Universal-Edition. Aus Anlass von Alfred Schlees 80. Geburtstag," Oesterreichische Musikzeitschrift 36 (December 1981): 639-45. Stephan's history of UE between 1938 and 1945 is restricted to two sentences: "Die Besetzung Oesterreichs zwang führende Männer in die Emigration (Kalmus, Roth, Heinsheimer) und veranlaßte eine Aenderung der Personalstruktur des Verlags; schließlich kam ein Großteil der Aktien in deutschen Besitz. Es dauerte lange, bis in die frühen fünfziger Jahre, bis alle die so entstandenen Wirren aufgelöst und alle Rechtsfragen geklärt werden konnten" .

15. To date Schott has apparently rarely allowed scholars access to its internal files; UE has recently initiated an in-house inventory and vetting of documents dating from 1933 to 1945, but they are not yet available to researchers. I am grateful, however, to Marion von Hartlieb, Managing Director of UE, and various department heads, who have answered specific inquiries and provided photocopies of key documents relevant to my research. In 1998, the German media conglomerate Bertelsmann appointed an internationally constituted panel of scholars to examine its disputed history during the Nazi era, when it became the leading publisher of reading material intended for German soldiers. In a preliminary report summarized in the New York Times, 18 January 2000, the commission reported that the company's earnings increased eleven-fold from 1938 to 1941 and that one of its family leaders, Heinrich Mohn, belonged to a circle of sponsoring members of the SS. After the war Mohn had explained that "on occasion in earlier years" he had contributed sums to the Nazi Party "in order to be left alone."

16. UE, for example, has deposited nearly 40,000 pieces of correspondence with its composers in the Musiksammlung der Wiener Stadt- und Landesbibliothek, including those of Schoenberg , Berg , Webern , Krenek , Schreker (1,805), Zemlinsky , Weill (1,428), Casella , Milhaud , Bartók , Kodály (1,124), and Janácek . In some of these cases, however, it is clear that these collections are not complete, especially during the period from 1933 to 1945. The most helpful overview of music publishing during this period is "Responding to the Market: Music Publishing in the Third Reich," Chapter 6 of Erik Levi's Music in the Third Reich (New York: St. Martin's Press, 1994), 147-65; hereafter cited within the text as MiTR. Surprisingly, Fred K. Preiberg is virtually silent about music publishing in Musik im NS-Staat (Frankfurt a. M.: Fischer Taschenbuch, 1982). Michael Meyer's Politics devotes a single page to the topic "Music Publishers and Dealers" (119-20).

17. The Paul-Hindemith-Institut, Franfurt am Main, holds photocopies only of the correspondence with Willy Strecker, as Hindemith's original letters are still in the possession of Schott; Strecker's letters to Hindemith survive only in carbon copies, also held by Schott. The letter is cited here by permission of Giselher Schubert, Director of the Paul-Hindemith-Institut.

18. Hans Werner Henze, Bohemian Fifths: An Autobiography, trans. Steward Spencer (London: Faber and Faber, 1998), 62; hereafter cited within the text as BFAA.

19. See Gudrun Breimann, Mathis der Maler und der "Fall Hindemith": Studien zu Hindemiths Opernlibretto im Kontext der kulturgeschichtlichen und politischen Bedingungen der 30er Jahre. (Frankfurt a. M.: Lang, 1997).

20. Hindemith wrote Willy Strecker on 26 April 1940: "I have had a long letter from Hugo regarding the transfer of the rights and possible reprint there. He makes some very good and farseeing proposals that will allow everything to be maintained here on a permanent basis without in principle making any changes in our mutual relationship--about which I am very glad" (trans. in Skelton, Selected Letters of Paul Hindemith, [New Haven: Yale University Press, 1995], 161-2, hereafter referred to as Letters of Hindemith). Associated Music Publishers (AMP) had been founded in 1927 by Paul Heinicke as an agency to represent European publishers, including both Schott and Universal Edition, in the United States. It was subsequently purchased by BMI (Broadcast Music Incorporated). After the war, AMP returned copyrights in many wartime compositions to the European parent firms. For example, on 8 November 1946, it assigned to Schott the copyright in Stravinsky's Danse concertante, Danse sacrale, and Symphony in Three Movements. This sort of "shell game," when successfully played, exempted such works from the administrative bureaucracy of agencies such as the U.S. Office of the Custodian of Alien Property, which administered copyrights that fell under the provisions of the Enemy Alien Act. In contrast, Weill requested the Custodian of Alien Property "to take over the copyrights" of Die Dreigroschenoper in 1942, because Felix Bloch Erben and Universal Edition "have been taken over long ago by the Nazis and since Die Dreigroschenoper was one of the first plays which was banned by the Nazi government" (Letter to Howard Reinheimer, 10 November 1942; copy in the Weill-Lenya Research Center, New York).

21. Letter from Hindemith to Willy Strecker, 30 May 1941; Letters of Hindemith, 177. In 1933, at the urging of Richard Strauss, Goebbels's Ministry had established STAGMA (Staatlich genehmigte Gesellschaft zur Verwertung musikalischer Urheberrechte) as a new system for collecting and distributing royalties for the use of copyright music. Even after they had been expelled from the Reichsmusikkammer or the country, many non-Aryan or otherwise undesirable composers were allowed to keep their memberships in STAGMA so that foreign royalties would continue to flow into Germany, where they were often then impounded. Kurt Weill, in contrast, had resigned from the German organization, effective 30 September 1933, and joined the parallel Italian society.

22. Hindemith quoted the letter from Kailey in his own letter to Karl Bauer at Associated Music Publishers, 15 June 1945; published in Letters of Hindemith, 186-88.

23. Letter from Heinsheimer to Weill, 21 June 1932.

24. On 3 April, Heinsheimer wrote Weill that "the last eight days have been so catastrophic that we are at present absolutely in the dark about the further conduct of German business. Director [Hugo] Winter has gone to Berlin in order to get information there and to see if there are any prospects at all there. Under such circumstances, we will have to ask you to accept 500 marks for April." Heinsheimer enclosed a personal note with the official letter: "We are naturally quite aware of your difficult position and will not leave you high and dry. But you must understand the disastrous situation in which we find ourselves. The German boycott, whose unofficial effects will be still worse than the official ones, hits us squarely in the face." Weill responded immediately: "I would like to say once again that I made a concession on this point only because the understanding and trust that you and UE have for my works seems great enough to warrant my making financial sacrifices, which are not easy for me at the present time" (3 April 1933).

25. The matter was finally resolved, after months of heated correspondence, in October 1933 at a meeting between Alfred Kalmus and Weill. The terms of the settlement were summarized in a letter from Weill to UE dated 19 November 1933: UE would pay Weill the reduced stipends, and Weill agreed to pay UE two percent of his future income deriving from his works, plus additional sums if his income should exceed 100,000 francs. Meanwhile, on 31 October 1933 Weill had signed a new contract with the Parisian music publisher Heugel.

26. For a more detailed account of Schlee's pre-1927 career, see Gunhild Oberzaucher-Schüller, ed., Schrifttanz: Eine Vierteljahresschrift. Schriftleitung Alfred Schlee. 1. Jahrgang 1928 bis 4. Jahrgang 1931. 11 Hefte und 2. Beihefte in einem Band. (Hildesheim: Georg Olms Verlag, 1991), 1-19. Among Schlee's essays are: "Wo steht Laban?" Der Tanz 2 (December 1929): 2--7; "The Modern German Dance," Theatre Arts (June 1930): 419-29; "The Stage at the 'Bauhaus'," Theatre Arts (April 1931): 343-50; "The Dance in Soviet Russia," The Dancing Times (July 1932): 339-43; "La musique de danse en Allemagne," Archives internationales de la danse (October 1933): 158-60.

27. On the appropriation of the Ausdruckstanz by Nazi aesthetics, see Susan Manning, Ecstasy and the Demon: Feminism and Nationalism in the Dances of Mary Wigman (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1993).

28. Schlee, "Expressionism in the Dance," Modern Music 8 (May-June 1931): 13. Thereafter Schlee was a regular contributor to the American journal: "Laban and the Berlin Staatsoper," 9 (Nov.-Dec. 1931): 24-27; "Under the Red Flag," 9 (Mar.-Apr. 1932): 108-13; "The Germans in Paris," 10 (Nov.-Dec. 1932): 42-46; "Decline of the Prima Ballerina," 11 (Nov.-Dec. 1933): 24-29; "German Opera in Transition," 11 (Mar.-Apr. 1934): 147-49; "Dancers in Germany Today," 12 (Jan.-Feb. 1935): 82-85.

29. The disk, Paloma 3501, also included Schlee accompanying Olga Antosch-Levko in Hanns Eisler's "Lied vom Trockenbrot"; the Weill song has been reissued on Capriccio CD 10 347. During rehearsals for Mahagonny, Pasetti and Lenya began an affair which lasted two years. In a strange twist of history, after World War II, as a commissioned officer in the U.S. Army, he served three six-month terms as de-nazification official for American occupation authorities in Austria--in charge of the cases of both Karl Böhm and Herbert von Karajan.

30. Letter from Heinsheimer to Weill, 28 January 1933.

31. Schlee, "German Opera in Transition," 147, 147.

32. Letter from Weill to Margarethe Kaiser, 1 May 1947; photocopy in the Weill-Lenya Research Center. It is not clear whether Weill's mention of "a letter from UE" refers to Schlee's of the previous September or another which has not been preserved.

33. Letter from Schlee to Weill, 17 January 1950.

34. After Hans Mersmann had been relieved of its editorship, Melos ceased publication in 1934; in November 1934 it reappeared for six issues as Melos Neue Folge and then Neue Musikblatt until the "total war" of 1943. See Hans Oesch, "Das Melos und die Neue Musik," in Festschrift für einen Verleger. Ludwig Strecker zum 90. Geburtstag, ed. Carl Dahlhaus (Mainz: B. Schott's Söhne, 1973), 287-94.

35. On 27 May 1938, Stravinsky wrote Willy Strecker: "Some friends who just came from Germany have informed me of an exhibition in Düsseldorf entitled "Entartete Musik" in which my name, along with that of Hindemith, heads the list. And this after the great success of Jeu de cartes and Perséphone (repeated the day before yesterday in Braunschweig), while Firebird is played . . . all over Germany!" On 6 August 1938, Stravinsky reported to Strecker that an official response to his protest had arrived: "you and your publisher may count on a benevolent neutrality." On 21 November 1938, Strecker reassured Stravinsky that "the exhibit seems already to have been forgotten in Germany." For an account of their reactions to the incident, see Stravinsky: Selected Correspondence, 3:265-70.

36. Microfilms of the personnel files of the Reichsmusikkammer, now in the Berlin Document Center, are held by the National Archives 2 on the campus of the University of Maryland in College Park. The Streckers' files can be found on reel A-3339-RKK-No. 36. A law effective 1 October 1934 required that all music publishers be card-carrying members of the Reichsmusikkammer.

37. Lys Symonette, née Bertlies Weinschenk, who lived in Mainz until 1936, recalls: "I remember Ludwig Strecker [Jr.] mostly as an ace tennis player, since he was invited to play in national tournaments. I shared gymnastic lessons with his daughters Elsbeth and Marion and also played a great deal of tennis with both of them. His only son, who went to school with my cousin Fritz, died in the war from a fever contracted at the Russian front. There had always been rumors that Ludwig Strecker was a Nazi, but he was probably too shrewd to become a registered party member. According to my friend Gretel, a violent anti-Nazi, Willy had never been a Nazi" (Letter to the author, 30 May 2000).

38. Stravinsky: Selected Correspondence, 218. Microfilms of both sets of documents are housed in the National Archives 2. Neither register, however, has survived intact.

39. See Albrecht Riethmüller, "Komposition im Deutschen Reich um 1936," Archiv für Musikwissenschaft 38 : 241-78, esp. 268-74. I am grateful to Professor Riethmüller for sharing with me information from his interview with Reutter. Reutter, though included by Hans Severus Ziegler in the "Entartete Musik" exhibition, enjoyed official recognition and support during the Third Reich as the director of the Frankfurt Musikhochschule. See also Erik Levi, "Atonality, 12-Tone Music and the Third Reich," Tempo 178 (Sept. 1991): 17.

40. Riethmüller reports that Schott advertised Reutter's and Andersen's cantata as "das neue Oratorium des deutschen Menschen" in Melos 12 : 259. See Riethmüller, "Komposition im Deutschen Reich um 1936," 270.

41. Strecker also provided the libretto for Joseph Haas's Tobias Wunderlich and Die Hochzeit des Jobs , and Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari's Der Kuckuck von Theben . See Karl Gustav Fellerer, "Ludwig Strecker und Joseph Haas in der Arbeit an Tobias Wunderlich," and Friedrich Schultze, "Einige Ueberlegungen und Anmerkungen zum Thema: Libretto," in Festschrift für einen Verleger, 191-202, 358-71.

42. See Zeitschrift für Musik (April 1942): 183.

43. Geoffrey Skelton, Paul Hindemith: The Man Behind the Music (New York: Crescendo, 1975), 120. Concerning Orff's works that were hidden away in Schott's poison cupboard, see Kim H. Kowalke, "Burying the Past: Carl Orff and His Brecht Connection," Musical Quarterly 84 (Spring 2000): 58-83.

44. Skelton, Paul Hindemith, 127.

45. Stravinsky apparently made no effort to refute an article ascribed to Richard Strauss, which appeared in a Nuremburg newspaper in 1934, stating that the composer was "enthusiastic about the ideas of Adolf Hitler." See Levi, MiTR, 99 (Levi incorrectly identifies the Fränkischer Kurier as a Frankfurt newspaper).

46. Edition Schott Nr. 2222, "Eine Sammlung der 222 schönsten Volks-, Wander- und Studentenlieder für Klavier, leicht spielbar, mit Text herausg. von L. Andersen." The texts were also issued alone, and an obligato violin part (Nr. 2223) also supplemented the original publication. In the 1940s, it was still featured on the back cover of the three volumes of Das neue Soldaten Liederbuch.

47. The two-volume Neues Deutschland appeared as Edition Schott 2324 and 2580. Edited by Erwin Schwarz-Reiflingen, the collection included "die meistgesungenen nationalen Lieder." Schott also issued Das Allotria-Buch, "fidele Lieder für fidele Gesellschaft," (Nr. 2590), Das frohe Rheinlieder-Buch, "die meistgesungenen Lieder vom Rhein und dem Wein," (Nr. 2500), and Soldaten singen alte und neue Lieder, bearb. F. Josef Breuer, for chromatic accordion (Nr. 2536).

48. Edition Schott 2799, 2888, 2899.

49. Several of these titles are among some 375 items in the "Nazi Imprint Collection" in the Ruth T. Watanabe Special Collections of the Sibley Music Library of the University of Rochester, assembled shortly after the war by agents of the Library of Congress, who deposited duplicate copies in major libraries in the United States.

50. Letter from Hindemith to Willy Strecker, 18 October 1939; trans. Skelton, Letters of Hindemith, 137-38. II. Uebungsbuch für den zweistimmigen Satz; I. Theoretischer Teil had appeared in 1937, also published by Schott.

51. Letter from Strecker to Hindemith, 7 February 1946, photocopy in Paul-Hindemith Institut.

52. Jürgen Schebera, Kurt Weill: An Illustrated Life (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1995), 208. Schott had commissioned Josef Müller-Blattau of the University of Königsberg to prepare the new edition.

53. Letter from Schoenberg to Berg, 16 October 1933; The Berg-Schoenberg Correspondence: Selected Letters, ed. Juliane Brand, Christopher Hailey, and Donald Harris (New York: Norton, 1987), 446.

54. Letter from Schreker to Schoenberg, 25 August 1933; quoted in Christopher Hailey, Franz Schreker 1878-1934: A Cultural Biography (London: Cambridge University Press, 1993), 291.

55. Letter from Schreker to Hans Heinsheimer, 16 June 1933; quoted in Hailey, Franz Schreker, 289.

56. Letter from Weill to Heinsheimer, 14 March 1933.

57. Letter from Berg to Schoenberg, 28 August 1935; The Berg-Schoenberg Correspondence, 467.

58. Letter from Heinsheimer to Weill, 24 January 1935.

59. Letter from Weill to Alfred Kalmus, 28 July 1937.

60. Letter from Kalmus to Weill, 6 August 1937. Kalmus also told Weill that "the artistic success of the year was Alban Berg's opera Lulu, which had received its posthumous premiere in Zurich." Although Max Reinhardt's production of Franz Werfel's and Weill's biblical spectacle The Eternal Road had run 153 performances at the Manhattan Opera House and garnered high critical praise, the huge weekly running costs, which exceeded even maximum box office income, prevented the producers from paying the authors any royalties.

61. In 1976 I found the newspaper clipping, identified only as "Lyon's Den (Post)," among "miscellaneous Weill clippings" in the collection of the Performing Arts Library at Lincoln Center. I have not yet been able to pinpoint its date of publication. No surviving correspondence between Weill and UE corroborates the assertion that Weill "wrote to his music publisher in Vienna and notified him that. . . a sale could be arranged." It may be just an embellishment of Weill's letter to Kalmus of 28 July 1937.

62. William Shirer, The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich: A History of Nazi Germany (New York: Simon & Schuster, 1960), 479.

63. The listing contradicts the conclusions of Kathryn Bailey, one of the few scholars who has tried to come to grips with the historical record of Webern's interactions with National Socialism: "Very soon Universal Edition was taken over by the Nazis, and both publication and performance of [Webern's] music were banned" (The Life of Webern [Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1998], 165).

64. Letter in German from Bartók to Frau Müller-Wedmann, 13 April 1938; Béla Bartók Letters, ed. János Demény, trans. Péter Balabán and István Farkas (London: Faber, 1971), 267-8.

65. Béla Bartók Letters, 276.

66. Goebbels, quoted in Entartete Musik: Dokumentation und Kommentar, 72.

67. Letter from Hindemith to Karl Bauer, 15 June 1945; Letters of Hindemith, 187. Schlee's account also confirms this scenario ("50 Jahre Danach," 191).

68. At the time of this writing, Dr. Johannes Petschull (b. 1901) was living in Königstein, near Frankfurt am Main. My letter to Dr. Petschull of 1 August 2000 was answered on 11 September by Karl Rarichs of C. F. Peters: "Unfortunately Dr. Petschull is ill and at 99 years of age, no longer in the position to answer your questions."

69. 1901 bis 1951 Universal Edition Wien, 10. Betty Rothe had been Hertzka's secretary.

70. Alfred Schlee mit Lothar Knessl, interview in "50 Jahre Danach," Oesterreichische Musik Zeitschrift 43 (April 1988): 191. In the same interview Schlee declared: "Meine Einstellung zum Nationalsozialismus war eindeutig. Als Student hatte ich ein einziges Mal eine Rede Hitlers gehört und es für unmöglich gehalten, daß dieser Mensch je einen bedrohlichen Erfolg werde haben können."

71. Interview by the author with Eva Smirzitz, Anni Taussig's neice, 30 June 2000. Eva recalled that when new regulations prohibiting Jews from possessing driving licenses were enacted, her aunt could bear no more persecution. Eva's father, who lost his job with Bayer Pharmaceuticals because the firm wanted no Aryan employees in mixed marriages with Jews, took over Schlee's apartment in Berlin in August 1938. His family joined him there in 1939. Schlee married almost immediately the diseuse Anna Marie Hegener, but he remained in amicable contact with his first wife's family.

72. See "50 Jahre Danach," 191.

73. Ibid.

74. Diary entry, 9 March 1942; quoted in "Meeting with Anton Webern (Pages from a Diary)," trans. John C. G. Waterhouse, Tempo 99 : 5. An analogous indictment had appeared as early as 1931 in the mouthpiece of the NSDAP, the Nationalsozialistische Monatshefte: "So the people that brought forth a Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, and Wagner need to be rejuvenated with Negro blood. . . . In summary, one can only say over and over again that Brechtian texts and Weillian music are never to be regarded as German art" (Dec. 1931, 378, quoted by Schebera, Kurt Weill: An Illustrated Life, 204).

75. Letter from Stefan G. Harpner to the author, 31 October 1999. Schlee credited Gottfried von Einem and his mother for their help. One of UE's salesmen, Rudolf Friedrich, hid the scores behind the organ at the monastery in Zwettl.

76. Cables from from UE to AMP, 1, 2 February; letter from 4 February 1952; photocopies in the Weill-Lenya Research Center, New York. See Kim H. Kowalke, "The Threepenny Opera: The Score Adapted," in Die Dreigroschenoper: A Facsimile of the Holograph Full Score, Kurt Weill Edition, Series 4, Volume 1 (Valley Forge, Pa.: European American Music, 1996), 11. UE had not printed a full score of Die Dreigroschenoper, as it supplied theaters with only a cued piano-conductor score. In 1985, during my first trip to Vienna as the administrator of Weill's legacy, I met Alfred Schlee, who was still serving as Artistic Director of UE at age 84. I requested to see the holograph score of Die Dreigroschenoper, which was on deposit at the Wiener Stadt- und Landesbibliothek. From his office in the Musikverein where pride of place was given over to Webern's piano, Schlee dispatched Karl Heinz Füssl, who had edited the score for the 1972 Philharmonia Partitur No. 400, to retrieve the manuscript. Füssl returned, score in hand, its frail overleaf covered with raindrops (their effects are still visible on it today). "It's pouring out there," he muttered. Rendered almost speechless with the realization that he had carried the holograph from the library without any protection whatsoever during a heavy rainstorm, I suggested that such treatment was inappropriate for so precious an artifact. Füssl laughed nervously, and, directing his comment more to Schlee than to me, said that "Weill and Eisler didn't care about such things anyway." Since 1998 all holograph scores of works published by UE have been on deposit in the Sibley Music Library at the University of Rochester.

77. The Eisler items included libretto, piano score, and choral parts of Die Maßnahme; Tagebuch; and many individual songs and Männerchöre. Weill's included "Berlin im Licht," the 1929 Song Album, the piano score and libretto of Aufstieg und Fall der Stadt Mahagonny, the choral parts for Das Berliner Requiem, and the piano score and libretto of Die Bürgschaft. These statistics were furnished to me by Universal Edition, and they may not be complete.

78. The Hungarian-born composer Bela Reinitz (1878-1943) had produced left-wing political compositions, especially workers' choruses, to texts by Brecht and Tucholsky. His Singspiel Schatten über Haarlem had been premiered in Vienna in 1930.

79. Lexikon der Juden in der Musik, ed. T. Stengel and H. Gerigk (Berlin: Bernhard Hahnefel Verlag, 1941), cols. 240-41.

80. See Stephen Hinton, "Die Dreigroschenoper: the 1928 Full Score," in Die Dreigroschenoper: A Facsimile of the Holograph Full Score, 6.

81. Herbert Fleischer gave this account to David Drew, who shared it with me in a letter of 3 September 1999. See also David Drew, Kurt Weill: A Handbook (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1987), 437-39.

82. Modern Music 23 (Spring 1946): 95-99. In this essay, Schlee says that "two works by Hanns Eisler which he had written to anti-fascist texts shortly before the Nazi occupation . . . were hidden in the home of Eisler's friend, Erwin Ratz, behind the flour sacks out of which he fed the Underground Railroad during the long years."

83. Ibid., 96. For a detailed account of Webern's work for Universal Edition, see Hans W. Moldenhauer, Anton von Webern: A Chronicle of His Life and Work (New York: Knopf, 1979), 534-36.

84. See Bailey, 154. Although Kathryn Bailey considers the full range of documentation, she does so with an obvious agenda: "damage control." In contrast, David Schroeder has utilized the same evidence to hypothesize that Webern's death at the hands of an American soldier may have been "assisted suicide." ("Not Proven: Was Webern's Death an Accident?" Musical Times [June 1996]: 21-23.)

85. "Mein Vater Anton Webern," Oesterreichische Musikzeitschrift 23 (June-July 1968): 332.

86. Peter Stadlen, contribution to the composite memoir "50 Jahre Danach," 195. Stadlen also recounts Eduard Steuermann's reactions to Webern's views of National Socialism.

87. Robert Craft, Notes to Anton Webern: The Complete Music (Columbia K4L 232), 6. In "Atonality, 12-Tone Music and the Third Reich," Erik Levi notes the success in the Third Reich of Winfried Zillig, another of Schoenberg's students, and Paul von Klenau, who defended the twelve-tone compositional principle as "totalitarian" and thus "entirely appropriate to the future direction of the 'National Socialist World.'" Levi speculates that if Webern had possessed a similar degree of political acumen, he might have been successful too, given the conflicting and haphazard non-racialist cultural policies of the Third Reich.

88. See Leon Botstein, "Preserving Memory," Musical Quarterly 83 (Fall 1999): 295-300; and Joseph N. Straus, "The Myth of Serial 'Tyranny' in the 1950s and 1960s," idem., 301-343.

89. Hans Werner Henze, Music and Politics: Collected Writings, 1953-81 (Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1982), 154.

90. Richard Taruskin, "Back to Whom? Neoclassicism as Ideology," Nineteenth Century Music 16 (Spring 1993): 301.

91. Whittall, 217. Whittall attempts to differentiate Webern's case from Wagner's, in which the evidence of a relationship between Wagner's anti-Semitism and his works is "impressive." Whittall objects to Richard Taruskin's characterization of Webern's String Quartet as his "most stringently constrained and dehumanized work" and invokes a trope on the "Webern as victim" conceit: "Taruskin can only offer opinion, supposition, not fact, and to see the music quite so abjectly reduced to the status of a sonic sponge absorbing external, cultural factors--though common in New Musicological writing--is unpersuasive to anyone who feels that, at the very least, the music's qualities transcend rather than helplessly implement its ideological content."

92. Pierre Boulez, Notes of an Apprenticeship, trans. Herbert Weinstock (New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1968), 268-76. "In any case we should guard against seeing Schoenberg as a sort of Moses who died in view of the Promised Land after having brought down the sacred Tablets of the Law from a Sinai that some people obstinately want to confuse with Valhalla. (Meanwhile, the 'Dance Round the Golden Calf' is in full swing.)"

93. In 1951 the firm was finally reinstated to its pre-war owners; Schlee emerged from the proceedings and negotiations as a minority shareholder in the new UE.

94. The August 1946 issue of the Oesterreichische Musikzeitschrift carries an advertisement by UE announcing the catalogue's acquisition of twenty new composers, including Gottfried von Einem, Friedrich Wildgans, Olivier Messiaen, Frank Martin, Luigi Dallapiccola, and Boris Blacher.

95. Anton von Webern, The Path to New Music, ed. Willy Reich (Bryn Mawr: Theodore Presser, 1963), 10; Anthony Tommasini, "Mid Century Serialists: The Bullies or the Besieged?," The New York Times, 9 July 2000.

96. Pierre Boulez, in the Revue musicale , trans. as "Serialism" and reprinted in Josiah Fisk, ed., Composers on Music: Eight Centuries of Writings, 2nd ed. (Boston: Northeastern University Press, 1997), 419.

97. Igor Stravinsky in Die Reihe: A Periodical Devoted to Developments in Contemporary Music, ed. Herbert Eimert and Karlheinz Stockhausen, vol. 2 Anton Webern (Bryn Mawr, Pa.: Theodore Presser in association with Universal Edition, 1955/8), vii. Ten years later, Stravinsky noted with regret that "the Webern cult [had] made the mistake of switching from the music to the musician, a barren devotion in any case, but especially so in this one because of the unexploitable nature of the mahatma-to-be." Nevetheless, he concluded, "If you are seeking strange gods you might do worse than continue to revere St. Anton." (Introductory Interview with Igor Stravinsky in Anton von Webern: Perspectives, comp. by Hans Modenhauer, ed. Demar Irvine [Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1966], xix, xxvii).

98. Letter (written in English) from Arnold Schoenberg to Kurt List, 17 October 1944; reprinted in Arnold Schoenberg, Letters, ed. Erwin Stein (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1978), 219. "It is perhaps not [Shostakovich's] fault that he has allowed politics to influence his compositional style. And even if it is a weakness in character--he might be no hero, but a talented musician."

99. Carl Dahlhaus, ed., Festschrift für einen Verleger: Ludwig Strecker zum 90. Geburtstag. Several contributions specifically address Schott's continuing role in the Gesamtausgaben of Wagner (Dahlhaus) and Schoenberg (Stephan).

100. Heinz Josef Herbort, "Der Geburtstag der Geburtshelfer: Der Komponist Pierre Boulez über das Verlegen von Musik," Die Zeit (15 November 1991), 70. I am grateful to Ilse Heinisch of Universal Edition, who provided me with a tape recording of Boulez's speech for the concert.

101. "50 Jahre Danach," 190-91. In a letter of 22 September 1999, Marion von Hartlieb informed me that UE did not have a copy of the entire "Gespräch" with Knessl: "It was never published because, according to Mr. Knessl's wife, Schlee never wanted it to be published." One is struck by the similarity to Carl Orff's restriction of the eight-volume documentation Carl Orff und sein Werk to "everything that the composer wished to have known about his career." It too makes little or no mention of his relationship to the Third Reich. "Let them pick over my bones after I'm dead," he told Andreas Liess (Carl Orff, trans. Adelheid Parkin and Herbert Parking [New York: St. Martin's Press, 1966], 27).

102. UE's press release, "Music Publisher Alfred Schlee Celebrates His 95th Birthday on 19 November 1996" offers few additional specifics: "His representation of UE for Germany, based in Berlin, took on a deeper significance when Hitler's takeover created a difficult situation between Universal Edition and German cultural institutions. Between 1938 and 1945, Schlee worked in Universal Edition's Vienna office. At that time, he successfully resisted the transfer of UE to Germany."

103. Even the most accurate and detailed obituaries [Gerhard Rohde, "Zum Tod des Musikverlegers Alfred Schlee," Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, 3 March 1999; Martin Anderson, "Alfred Schlee," The Independent (London), 22 March 1999] derive entirely from the press release and previously published official histories of UE. The obituaries do not mention Schlee's first two wives, but only Margarethe Molner, whom he married in 1960 and with whom he had two sons.

104. Letter from Lenya to Mary Daniel; quoted in David Farneth, ed., Lenya, the Legend: A Pictorial Autobiography (New York: Overlook Press, 1998), 142.

105. See Richard Taruskin, "The Dark Side of Modern Music," The New Republic (5 Sept. 1988), 28-34.

8.1 159-172

[Access article in PDF]

Review Essay

Culture Clubs

Douglas Mao
Harvard University

Patterns for America: Modernism and the Concept of Culture. Susan Hegeman. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1999. Pp. x + 264. $55.00 (cloth); $17.95 (paper).

What was modernism's relation to the concept of culture? To those of us who have spent some time with modernism, at least two kinds of answer might suggest themselves right away. One would fix on modernism's ambivalent entanglement with "high culture" at its demandingly highest, and find its icons in writers like T. W. Adorno (railing against the culture industry on behalf of a bleak and difficult art) or better still T. S. Eliot (author not only of a poem whose forbidding learnedness helped to secure its eminence but also, thirty years later, of Notes reporting that evidence of cultural decline "is visible in every department of human activity"). 1 The other sort of answer would play upon a rather different sense of "culture": here, res like the Picasso of Les demoiselles d'Avignon or the Conrad of Heart of Darkness would evoke modern Western art's fascination with non- Western people, objects, and texts, and more generally the essential "modernism" of cross-cultural contact on an unprecedented scale. The high-culture response and the other-culture response both attest to the intimacy of modernism and "culture," of course; but contemplated together they also appear as poles of a contradiction that can seem--to anyone worn out by the "culture wars" of the 1990s, and quite apart from questions about modernism per se--more bothersome than generative. The prescriptive sense of the oh-so-tired term bids it be esteemed right into impossibility ("culture," since Matthew Arnold, as the perfection of knowledge and manners that no one can quite achieve); the descriptive one looks ample to the point of meaninglessness ("culture" as a totality hard to differentiate from society itself). Why mess with it anymore?

In her savvy and important new book, Patterns for America: Modernism and the Concept of Culture, Susan Hegeman faces squarely the irritation that "culture" currently produces, arguing both that the slipperiness of the term is a reason to prize rather than dismiss it, and that attempts to negotiate between the aforementioned (and still other) meanings proved crucial to the shaping of a modernism whose consequences continue to be felt. According to her, "the lineaments of many of the most visible contemporary debates about 'culture' are residua of the early Cold War era," and the origins of Cold War formulations themselves to be discerned in confrontations transpiring in the preceding decades . It was during the heyday of modernism that those most concerned with America's ills and possibilities came routinely to invoke "culture" in their diagnoses; it was in the 1930s most acutely, as Warren Susman has argued, that Americans came "to do two new things: to understand themselves as participating in a distinctive 'American' culture, and to see this culture as a set of patterns, values, and beliefs roughly comparable to those of other cultures" . For her, in other words, the roots of our own multicultural panics and pleasures lie in the young century's effort to fulfill at a stroke culture's descriptive and prescriptive mandates--to conceive of an American culture whose virtues would be those of both an American culture (an achieved, coherent culture where none had existed before) and an American culture (not better than any other, but right for Americans where any other would be wrong).

To represent Hegeman's book this way is to make it sound rather more like Our America --Walter Benn Michaels's strenuously provocative effort to intervene in the culture wars through a reading of modernism--than it does in its own voice. Still, it's worth noting up front that in spite of important disagreements (to be considered further on), she shares his belief that the crucial link between modernism and the concept of culture lies in a set of interlocked anxieties about identity and relativism. For her, then, the new understanding described by Susman is rendered "complexly modernist" not only by its siting in the first half of the twentieth century, but also by the "estranged perception of collective identity" that it enables, its allusion to "the construction of group identities of a decidedly uneasy and reflexive kind" . Like Michaels, Hegeman is interested in how unease and reflexivity play around res such as the immigrant and the Indian (Do they represent an alien culture, or the most authentically American culture?), and like him, she finds Americanness at issue in virtually all treatments of culture by American writers of the period. But where his main project is to disclose logics of culture and identity as these materialize in prose fiction, she asks, in addition, where the double sense of "culture" came from, and how it migrated to the realm of literature, high and low.

Her answer is that one origin, at least, lay in what was coalescing, in the early years of the century, as an academic discipline with its own anxieties and enthusiasms. Early in Patterns for America, Hegeman describes as "typically modernist" a certain oft-told tale in which the "'Arnoldian' view of culture as the attainment of social and aesthetic perfection" is "swept away" by "what is often called the 'anthropological' definition of the term, which is more synonymous with custom, connoting both the special and the mundane life ways of a given group of people" . The heroes of this "modernist" story aren't poets, novel-writers, or artists, however, nor is the scene of combat the Paris of Picasso or the London of Arnold, Eliot, and Conrad. Rather, the leading personae are the Columbia University anthropologist Franz Boas and his students; the scene is New York City; and the tale is, precisely, that of how comparative ethnography propelled a rethinking of culture and value that retains its hold on us today.

Hegeman isn't greatly concerned to disburden this story of its heroism, but she does revisit it with an impressive array of reconsiderations and nuances, foremost among them the point that in implicitly opposing (new, good, democratic) ethnography to (old, Arnoldian, hierarchical) literary cultivation, the received story obscures important connections between the Columbia anthropologists and a number of influential literati centered in Greenwich Village during the same years. These connections form the heart of Patterns for America, which--as much intellectual group biography as it is a reading of culture and modernism--might with no loss of aptness have been called Anthropologists and Bohemians in New York, 1918 to 1960, or Greenwich Village to Morningside Heights: An Interdisciplinary Legacy. Yet there's nothing misleading about the title the book does have, for Hegeman shows convincingly how sympathies and disagreements within her loose New York constellation set the terms for much larger debates about the forms of American culture--and in so doing manages nimbly the feat (precious to post-Geertzian anthropology and new historicist literary analysis alike) of drawing broadly consequential inferences from elaborations of specific milieux.

Initially, Hegeman's favored procedure is to pair anthropologists with intellectuals-at-large, in each instance strengthening the case for metaphorical alignment (the two res had similar backgrounds and ideas) with an appeal to metonymy (the two res were linked by the Columbia-Village nexus). In chapter two, for example, she notes in passing that Randolph Bourne was a student of Boas's colleague John Dewey, while considering in some detail how opposition to American intervention in World War One led both Boas and Bourne to their most important contributions to the evolving discourse of culture. (For both, American intolerance of German difference made imperative the defense, if not the articulation, of a relativist cultural pluralism.) In three, she shows how the problem of individual agency within cultural production led both Van Wyck Brooks and Edward Sapir--who shared "the same general social milieu as Boas and Bourne"--to powerful doubts about the very possibility of an authentically valid American culture . And in four, she argues that Ruth Benedict and Waldo Frank are worth reading together not only because of Frank's journalistic connections to Benedict's friend and mentor Sapir, but also because both turned to a "loose federalism" of regional cultures "geographically remote from urban America" for help in resolving the impasses that defeated Sapir and Brooks . Illuminating as this kind of pairing may be, however, it can stand only so much interpretive pressure before it becomes rigid, and Hegeman is alert to that danger. Accordingly, she enriches the Boas-Bourne material with a fresh take on Eliot, the Brooks-Sapir with a look at Alfred Kroeber's notion of "the superorganic," the Benedict-Frank with readings of Jean Toomer and Sherwood Anderson. She abandons the dyadic approach wholly when it ceases to serve, putting Constance Rourke, Kenneth Burke, Robert and Helen Lynd, Thomas Hart Benton, Nathanael West, and others in suggestive array in chapter five, and visiting Benedict, Brooks, Margaret Mead, Dwight Macdonald and James Agee in six.

One advantage of the New York focus is that it enables Hegeman to avoid, very cleanly, one of the traps into which certain historicists (Michaels especially) have been known to fall: that of making appeals to zeitgeist or epistemic rupture unsupported by attention to the paths by which ideas are transmitted and the conditions under which ideological positions mature. It's not that she regards personal contact or shared environments as the necessary foundation of comparison, as if absorption of topics en l'air and undocumented acts of reading and listening aren't the powerful forces they always are; on the contrary, her focal pairs tend to be more distantly connected than other couples that she might have treated at length. (Benedict and Frank, for example, shared nothing like the bonds that linked Benedict to Mead and Sapir.) In its particular way of attending to the Village-Columbia nexus, however, her work answers a demand made by Raymond Williams--but forgotten by some of Williams's less careful admirers--that individuals' experiences, and particularly their experiences of large social forces, be considered as factors in the generation of ideas. True, there are moments when she turns inopportunely from intriguing conceptual problems to blander biographical rationales. When she describes Brooks's tendency to resort to binaries as "a fascinating example of a repetition compulsion," or when (on slender evidence) she traces writers' worries about cultural community to disappointment with the New York scene itself, I hear the note of explanation-through-trauma that is one of contemporary biography's least fortunate tendencies (74, 59, 91, 98). But such moments are rare. More typical is her superb elucidation of how the professionalizing of anthropology and literary criticism affected her subjects' address to national culture, or her canny reading of Agee's recourse to personal recollection in Let Us Now Praise Famous Men--a fitting culmination to her exploration of middle-class guilt's refraction through non-middle-class others in writing of the Cold War and before.

Another reason why biographical sympathies serve Patterns for America so well is that they resonate with a theme that preoccupies Hegeman's subjects: How is individual freedom to be reconciled with the demand of social cohesion? This is, of course, the governing dilemma of liberalism, and as she notes it has shadowed cultural prescription at least since Arnold's recommendation that citizens transcend their "ordinary selves" in favor of "best selves" joined by a cultural glue. Her early chapters show illuminatingly how U.S. writers, confronting both the contradictions of Arnold's "cheery mysticism" and the new world's apparent poverty of tradition, sought to reframe the problem in distinctively American terms . Brooks, for example, tried to imagine a fusion of the spiritual yet desiccated "Puritan" element with that of the practical but unprincipled "Pioneer," yet found in the very intransigence of this binary (and its subsequent incarnations) a split within the middle-class self that culture could never heal. Sapir, in Hegeman's account, came to a similarly unhappy conclusion when he tried to apply his definition of culture as the embodiment of "the national genius" to the case of the United States . And in a provocative reading of Benedict's Patterns of Culture , she argues that the anthropologist's much discussed contrast between the "Apollonian" Zuni of New Mexico and the "Dionysian" Kwakiutl of Vancouver Island may have less to do with the difference between sobriety and ecstasy than with the tension between communal and individual that subtended less veiled period imaginings of the American utopia.

Benedict is the hinge of Hegeman's narrative, as her title might suggest, because her thinking touches, on one side, intellectuals bounded by a more or less Brooksian staging of the problem, and, on the other, a set of mostly younger writers who turned to regionalism for relief from the Arnoldian malady. This second group tried to reconcile diversity with national genius by imagining a country of multiple coherent cultures among which one, some, or none might be privileged as the genuine American article; and it's when she turns to these formulations that she really hits her stride. If the first part of Patterns for America is often insightful, the second is frequently brilliant. Here, a sensitive explication of Sherwood Anderson's Poor White illustrates how a sentimentalized Midwest came to contain America's diversity in the double sense of including it and expunging it; here, an analysis of restless hands in Anderson and Nathanael West illustrates how "Anderson, once held as the exemplar of a new, indigenous American modernist aesthetic, becomes the source of a grotesque representation of the frustrated desires of the middlebrow" (124, 156). Fine as these close readings are, however, the greater strength of this part of the book lies in its ambitious reconstruction of regionalism's role in the culture wars of the interwar years. Working up from instances like Thomas Hart Benton's 1935 response to Diego Rivera (in which Benton replaces Marxism's proletarian version of "the people" with a middle-class and implicitly Midwestern "common man" [142]), she presents an economical, yet extraordinarily powerful, overview of how visions of difference based on region clashed with visions based on class throughout the thirties. Nor is she less suggestive when she winds up the thread of high regionalism's fate. Could the "deep anxiety about cultural loss" felt by forties and fifties intellectuals, she wonders, derive from a kind of spectacular demise of region itself? Might "the increasing globalization of 'American culture'" not have "suggested the increasing difficulty of locating a position for the intellectual to inhabit that was critically exterior to the (global) social whole" (170-1)?

It may be that no critical work ever fails to enact one or two of the problems it describes, and Patterns for America does leave one asking how closely its New York particular represented the American general. The jacket copy promises a tracking of how "the term 'culture' changed from being a technical term associated primarily with anthropology into a term of popular usage," and this promise is handsomely fulfilled in several ways. Hegeman shows concretely how the New York groups disseminated their ideas through anthropological best-sellers, small but influential magazines, government-university partnerships, and other channels; she also usefully spotlights some anti-New York, antihighbrow reactions, notably Time magazine's promotion of Benton and Anderson as regionalists defending sane middle-American representationalism from, respectively, French abstraction and the literary "vagaries of the Da-da school" . Still, I felt a twinge of doubt on encountering the implication that a "widespread consensus over 'culture'" in the thirties enveloped not only "writers, photographers, social crusaders, [and] bureaucrats" but also many an average Joe and Jane, and found myself wondering how culture was actually regarded by more pedestrian residents of places that the New York groups made iconic of regionalism. What were inhabitants of the real New Mexico, the real Ohio, the real Los Angeles thinking ? And what was on the mind of Chicago, a place that Hegeman shows to have been on New Yorkers' minds to a surprising degree? How did Harriet Monroe--hardly an ordinary citizen, certainly, but a Chicagoan in spite of her international connections--feel about culture, regionalism, and identity?

The foregoing isn't a substantial complaint, only a question, and I doubt that many readers will fault Hegeman for failing to cover every last take on culture from the First World War to the Cold. The name of Monroe, however, points to what some will find a more serious absence following from the New York focus, that of extended attention to the expatriate writing still regarded by many as the centerpiece of American modernism. Except for Eliot (about whom more in moment), the expates receive only passing mention here--references to Pound, Stein, and H.D. are few--and even stay-at-home biggies like Stevens, Faulkner, and Moore scarcely surface. 2 To this objection, Hegeman responds by stating plainly that modernism is for her "first and foremost a periodizing concept, characterized by a nexus of related historical, intellectual, technological, and aesthetic developments, rather than . . . a set of formal traits or styles," and by arguing that to hand modernism over wholly to "the cosmopolitan avant-gardes of a few European capitals" is to adopt a view that is "impoverished in its explanatory power" and is more rather than less open to charges of provincialism (19-21). She then offers a précis of recent work on modernism as a historical phenomenon so crisply compact that one might recommend it as a primer for readers outside the field--just as one might hand Patterns for America as a whole to non-anthropologists interested in learning something about that discipline's history. Of course, none of this will satisfy those for whom modernism is a set of formal traits or styles, let alone those who take it to mean a specific canon of authors or works. (Even these, however, might grant Hegeman's claim to the extent that earlier chapters set the stage for her climactic reading of Cold War fabricators of modernism like Macdonald and Clement Greenberg.)

For my money, the muting of expatriate modernism per se offers less occasion for regret than does another omission, that of transatlantic contexts for the American debates Hegeman examines. The book's opening discussion of how "culture" sometimes overlaps with and sometimes opposes "civilization" in writers like Bourne, Sapir, and Lewis Mumford is useful, but it would have been more helpful still if it had engaged more directly with Raymond Williams's work on the tension between these terms in nineteenth-century British discourse, or Norbert Elias's rendering of its inauguration under German Romanticism. (These genealogies would be significant in any case, but they're all the more resonant here because, like Hegeman, both Elias and Williams take very seriously the question of historical actors' experience of social pressures.) 3 As just noted, also, the only American expatriate who receives substantial consideration is T. S. Eliot, but the treatment here fails to engage his most relevant polemic, Notes towards the Definition of Culture . Her early reading of "The Dry Salvages" in relation to developments in anthropology is stimulating, as is her note on the spatialization of culture discernible in After Strange Gods . After this point, however, Eliot all but disappears from the radar, which is odd because Notes makes so many of the pluralist moves that Hegeman explores in other writers. True, Eliot's concern isn't the United States but the United Kingdom (which in his view should remain politically single but culturally multiple: English, Welsh, Scottish, Irish); true also, the texts that she finds most salient in regionalism appeared well before 1949. Yet 1949 isn't beyond the temporal scope of Patterns for America as a whole, and it would surely have been illuminating to put Eliot's later cultural federalism into dialogue with the turn taken by postwar American critics. 4

And speaking of postwar American critics: If the light treatment given Eliot's Notes is a little curious, downright strange is the absence of explicit reference to Lionel Trilling's Beyond Culture , which speaks to Hegeman's concerns more immediately than any other product of the Partisan Review milieu. In his preface to that collection, Trilling not only worries about how far New York (and especially Columbia) intellectuals may presume to speak for a larger society, but also addresses this problem by way of the two meanings of "culture" to which Hegeman recurs (in his rendering: "that complex of activities which includes the practice of the arts and of certain intellectual disciplines," and "a people's technology, its manners and customs, its religious beliefs and organization, its systems of valuation"). 5 Moreover, the governing supposition of Beyond Culture is that "a primary function of art and thought is to liberate the individual from the tyranny of his culture in the environmental sense and to permit him to stand beyond it in an autonomy of perception and judgment." 6 In other words, Trilling here (as in other books like The Liberal Imagination) confronts both the problem of individual agency within culture and a problem of epistemological totality that, as we'll see in a moment, surfaces in the last pages of Patterns for America. Might it be that at some stage in the preparation of Hegeman's book, Trilling was its explicitly presiding genius? As things stand, he remains its (almost) silently presiding ghost.

II.

One omission with which Hegeman can't be charged is a failure to address contemporary battles over "culture." In her last chapter, she applies her insights into the term's genealogy to the question of its place and usage in the United States today, which is to say that Patterns for America, again like Michaels's Our America, is a reading of modernism and culture that has something significant to say to readers with no interest in modernism as such. Confronted with an infinite number of possible approaches to the question, Hegeman elects to examine "arguments that have been made recently by both anthropologists and literary scholars for the complete abandonment of 'culture' as a critical term"--arguments that she would not represent as a "dominant, or even an emergent, view among people invested in . . . things widely thought of as 'cultural'" but that do give some purchase on inclinations and agendas underlying a range of debates on culture today.
