And then the way they feel about the dead, it is so friendly so simply friendly and though inevitable not a sadness and though occurring not a shock. There is no difference between death and life in France and that too made it inevitable that they were the background of the twentieth century. [PF, 13]

In this eternally ancient nation from which the twentieth century grows, among the fatalistic citizens who will pass mildly away, children become the locus for Stein's characterization of the costs and the effects of war. When Paris France shifts from descriptions of the country and its place in history to an attempt to address the experience of wartime more directly, Stein turns our attention to a little girl who lives near her in the village of Bilignin. 22 She makes the shift to childhood for several reasons. Her understanding of space and time has long deliberately retained something of the flexibility, the synchronicity of a child's. 23 Those who live in the state of temporal suspension that characterizes late 1939 and early 1940 in France live to some degree outside of time's ordinary progress, as children do. They seem to be equally helpless, as well, unable to control whatever is about to happen. This village girl also allows Stein to examine her own earlier days as a writer. Using the girl's name as a trigger for her backward glance, Stein returns, in a textual representation of memory, to a prior form of art--what has become, by 1939, one of her most famous instances of avant-garde, noninstrumental writing--now measured against words differently employed. One of Stein's strategies for assessing the meaning of the coming of war is to see what happens when a word slips from a wholly linguistic field of play into a time, a place, a body.

The word is "Button." It has gone from part of a title--Tender Buttons--to a girl's last name: Helen Button. But before we listen to Helen's wartime experience, we must first recall the sketch that famously opens Tender Buttons, under the heading "Objects." Stein presents us with the portrait of an object that is comparatively impervious to time:

A CARAFE, THAT IS A BLIND GLASS

A kind in glass and a cousin, a spectacle and nothing strange in a single hurt color and an arrangement in a system to pointing. All this and not ordinary, not unordered in not resembling. The difference is spreading. 24

The tensions between the familiar and the strange in this passage will return to haunt Helen Button. Even the ordinary attributes of this carafe have turned unsettling: the adjective "blind" disconcertingly suggests the possibility of the object becoming a subject capable of returning our scrutiny, just as "hurt" may point ratively to color but gestures also toward a body. Though this object is "not unordered in not resembling," though it has discernible form, is an "arrangement in a system to pointing," we are not initiated into the design of that system, the category in which its lack of resemblance would seem merely another instance of order. Different from expectations, familiar as kin and cousin might seem, but also, if looked at again or awry, less than kind, less known than novel, this carafe is a spectacle whose hard-edged indeterminacies threaten to overwhelm the observer and the observer's methods for making sense: "The difference is spreading."

Before we watch Helen Button staring at a kindred object in Paris France--as though she were looking at one of the items from Tender Buttons transposed, twenty-five years later, on the eve of the next war, to a village in Southeastern France--we witness her transformation from a little girl to a character in a story by Stein: "We have had here in the village a little girl and her name is Hélène Bouton, Helen Button" (PF, 80). 25 Hélène Bouton's imperfect reflection in Helen Button signals the difference between life and narrative and inaugurates a double act of recollection--of a French girl and of a highly charged English word from Stein's prior text that shares Helen's last name. Stein undertakes the complex act of recollection emphasizing that all portraits should take the measure of and unfold self-consciously in time, particularly when time carries such heavy freight: "because after all this war is not war," she adds in her opening, "it is war-time" (PF, 80). This war is "not war" because it has commenced without fully, violently beginning in earnest for the French. All of Stein's writings about war will explore the myriad ways in which the state of wartime itself can at once seem all-encompassing and wholly irrelevant to anyone living during war. Every sentence in her work that measures the full effect of living under war's terrible dispensations is followed shortly by a companion sentence that shows the subject virtually untouched by circumstances we associate with conflict. And not only does Stein underscore her subject's divided modes of being in time. She also encourages us to look beyond particulars, so that the local Hélène becomes the more general, more textual Helen, who lives not simply in late 1939 but in a widespread historical condition we call "war-time," stretching back even to the Iliad, where we will also find this girl's name. "She lived somewhere," Stein impatiently assures us, knowing that we will naturally gravitate toward the pathos of a specific case history and thereby be likely to miss the even more sobering truth that there are millions of Helens existing in time and space, their fates echoing across the centuries like the ticking of a clock. "[B]ut the thing that is important is that she lived during war-time. There is a great deal of war-time in history and Helen Button lived in it" (PF, 81). Stein introduces her portrait as a story about "what a child's feeling about war-time is" (PF, 80). Helen Button, we find, has spent many of her days and nights anxiously immersed in history.

Stein's story of Helen occupies ten enormously complex pages of Paris France, and yet it is with the first, deliberately framed narration of an event in Helen Button's life that her last name and the event together recall Tender Buttons. Stein now restages the opening of her earlier work, providing us with an object and a perceiving subject:

Helen Button started out with her dog William. As they were walking along suddenly William stopped and was very nervous. He saw something on the road and so did Helen. They neither of them knew what it was at first and at last as they approached very carefully they saw it was a bottle, a bottle standing up right in the middle of the road. There had been something in the bottle but what, it looked dark green or may be blue or black, and the bottle was standing up in the middle of the road, not lying on its side the way a bottle on the road usually is.
William the dog and Helen the little girl went on. They did not look back at the bottle. But of course it was still there because they had not touched it.
That is war-time. [PF, 82]

The passage resists reading as forcefully as did its antecedent in Tender Buttons. And this kindred moment is explicitly concerned with the effects of that resistance on two emblematical interpreters who share nervousness though their differences from each other extend even to their species. The familiar open vista of the road suddenly contracts around an object needing to be deciphered, threatening in its pure opacity. That mere object, the bottle of indeterminate color, demands interpretation because Helen and William are searching for what Stein, three paragraphs earlier, has called "signs" that will orient them in their ominously unfolding presents. The somehow crucial difference--that this bottle stands up rather than lying on its side--seems fraught with meaning in part because there is so little to interpret, so little to hold on to in this scene that epitomizes Helen and William's continually menacing, largely uneventful lives in wartime.

The difference, too, between this nonincident and "A CARAFE THAT IS A BLIND GLASS" augments its already considerable power. When Stein's object returns on this road, changed but related to a precedent object in Tender Buttons, and when we watch this girl and her dog equally though differently afraid of its possible significance, we confront a representative anxiety about failing to make meaning. Circumstances demand interpretation but leave us with insufficient points of reference by which we might venture to make sense of things. Tender Buttons does not stand as a key in relation to this later scene; the echoes do not help us read this different world. Our own acts of recollection simplify nothing. Brooding over history is as existentially mystifying to Stein as is being in the present, but those twin mystifications are most upsetting and most obvious during war. The comforting appositives, "the dog" and "the little girl" try, with only partial success, to reassemble William and Helen after their misadventure. But the bottle, Stein carefully insists, opening a space in her narrative for memory's continued, hysterical workings, "was still there because they had not touched it." Helen and William do not look over their shoulders, but the narrative glances back, forcing us to acknowledge that the impervious object remains to be recalled. Being in wartime exacerbates the tendency for the subject to fall into a seemingly infinite variety of disorders, leaving the inner and outer interpretable worlds incoherent, filled only with difference and unspeakable absences. The faculty of memory allows (or is condemns a better word?) the repeated return to these moments of difference, just as this brief scene circles back on itself. Stein's sketch of the displaced Helen and William holds out to them and to her readers the possibility, at once terrible and promising, of recollection. Not looking at the bottle but seeing it all the same, they know that there is something--a world--still there "because they had not touched it."

As the story of Helen Button in wartime continues, Stein displays, in the compressed narrative of her character's life, experiences and patterns of thought that will characterize her subsequent writing about the war. Helen's is a world where no relation--between people, with animals, with objects themselves, and even with the ostensible enemy--can be relied upon; where the urge to embrace prophecies, or hold to any system of signs that will allow the comforting sense that the future is foreknown and follows a plan is continually offset by even the most ordinary, expected events going wrong; where the laws of cause and effect seem suspended; where the familiar turns horrific and the anticipated nightmare does not materialize. Helen watches her friend Emil's dog, Ellen, "changing and her fur turned into large baggy trousers and her head turned into a large shaggy head and it was a man, an enemy man" (PF, 86). 26 She clings to her Aunt Pauline, who knows what the future holds--an extremely consequential gift of sight in these days, since "in war-time anything might happen so it was very necessary to know it" (PF, 87). 27 When the unexpected does occur (Aunt Pauline's lucidity has no observable effect on this story), consequences remain puzzling. Helen's dog is hit by a car: "The automobile came on, it went over William and Helen screamed and William was down and then he was up and then away he went, oh how he did go" (PF, 89). Shortly after this misadventure, a wagon comes by, carrying an unidentified "animal": "nobody had ever seen any animal like it before, it was enormous and it was dead. . . . The enormous animal did not have a tail and it did not have any ears. It was an enormous animal and it was war-time. Helen did not really see it but she told herself about it" (PF, 89-90). The last event in the story of Helen Button's life is, fittingly, her encounter with the enemy. Modernity and life within "the modern composition," to use Stein's phrase, means living exiled from the quiet confines of an imagined and secure self, without an island haven, lacking words alone. To be modern is to be forced, perhaps as one writes for a general public or gives lectures before anonymous audiences, often by the frightfully effective mechanism of war, into contact with the irreducible mystery of others. It is to live always in the state of wondering "who goes there?" Helen and Emil, her French friend with the German name, see a young man on a nearby hill with a spy glass. They decide on a patriotic course of action:

Emil went up to the man. He said to him. You are an enemy. I am not, said the man. If you are not what is your name said Emil. My name is Henry said the man.

There they stood and the snow in the fields and the water splashing and the man in wooden shoes, looking through his spy-glass at something.

What should they do.

It really was war-time.

They all went away always looking behind.

Very soon then there was nobody anywhere.

This is war-time.

Helen did not know why but this was the first thing in war-time that had made her cry. [PF, 91-2]

She grieves for herself and her precarious condition, for the vacuity of a crowded world. She knows that looking back will no more resolve the question of this stranger's allegiance than it will establish the meaning of the bottle in the road, and that going away makes as much sense as any other choice she and Emil might have taken, though it accomplishes nothing. She is still young, and the war continues, but she now understands all that can be known of her condition, "So for her," Stein explains, "war-time was over" (PF, 92). In the same bleak but resolved frame of mind, Stein casts a glance back over what she has just written and concludes, "So this is the twentieth century" (ibid.).

Stein in Life: Victory and the Problems of Naming

One of the most terrible aspects of Stein's portrait of Helen Button is that the girl vanishes in tears from Stein's narrative, never to reappear. Triumph over the enemy does not form part of her story. Stein, on the other hand, experiences the complex euphoria of liberation. I turn now to two pieces she wrote after V-E Day, one describing a trip she takes to Germany with the United States Army, the other containing her thoughts about the atomic bomb. Jean Gallagher who, in The World Wars Through the Female Gaze, discusses a number of Stein's World War II writings, argues that, "In Stein's postliberation writing, not only do we see a marked turn toward more detailed visual description and a willingness to interpret visual data for readers, but we also see how Stein participates in a militarized gaze." 28 It is certainly true that Stein's Wars I Have Seen records the coming of the Americans in greatest detail and vehemently celebrates the Allied victory. I do not agree, however, that she allows herself to see more clearly or with increased specificity--in this text or in others written in 1945-6--than she did before the arrival of her countrymen. Nor, I think, does Stein consistently write with an interpretive certainty she lacked before the defeat of the Germans. Rather, I suggest, the United States press catches her up in its representations for the American public of the liberation of France. Her writing about the war and her attitude toward the coming of the Americans make national news. So powerful are the public narratives of victory, and so compelling is the story of this artist's liberation, that Stein finds herself speaking (and being quoted) in public venues that discourage ambiguity, even though she herself continues to interrogate the war and its legacies. 29 The war correspondents, Eric Sevareid and Frank Gervasi, report Stein's "liberation" to the American press; stories about her are carried in many American periodicals; Stein herself makes a broadcast to America. 30 A continual stream of American officers and enlisted men come to her house in Culoz for visits. 31 She appears in a film, A G.I. Sees Paris. 32 Coming out of her necessary retreat in the French countryside during the war, Stein is thrust back into the public eye as fully as she was after the Autobiography was published. And she measures that publicity and the consequences of victory every bit as thoughtfully as she weighed the success and the effects of her own prose in the mid-1930s. She lives now, at the end of the European war, in a time of resolutions, when so many are busily providing answers and explanations and retrospective interpretations. Her own project in this last year of the war becomes a questioning of conclusions. What she demonstrates again, in this next phase of her writing about the war, is her ability to capture the essential oddity of war and its aftermath. Few writers can speak with such peculiar authority about the surreal in the ordinary and the ordinary in what we thought was apocalyptic.

Stein's most explicit return to her mass audience occurs in her appearance as an official witness of the Allied victory before the readers of Life magazine in August of 1945. 33 She begins her essay, "'Off We All Went to See Germany,'" with the insistent invitation of a corporal:

I think you'd better come and make a trip over Germany said Bob Sweet. Bob Sweet is a corporal in the 441st Troup Carrier Group and he is full of ideas and I usually do whatever he tells me to do. [Life, 54]

There is a great deal of humor in this essay, and it is humor of a kind that is likely to meet with the approval of Stein's American readers: "But Bob, I said, I don't like Germans, I saw enough of them in France I don't want to see them at home" (ibid.). She assures us, by the end of the first paragraph, that we need not be concerned that we will hear too much about Hitler's defeated nation: "And I really pretty well forgot about Germany and the Germans in the enormous pleasure of living intimately with the American Army" (Life, 54). The essay already begins to complicate its ostensible purpose. This will be a visit to see Germany in which not many Germans and not much of the country needs to be seen. She reduces that country to a nonentity in prose that is startling in its simplicity, as innocent of martial fervor or vengeful pleasures as the musings of Helen Button or her friend Emil. The editors of Life smile at her throughout, adding a section heading, for example, to her observations about the effects of Allied bombs on Cologne. "Roofs are important, yes," the editor of Stein's essay agrees with Stein, in pleased condescension at her own description:

Cologne was the most destroyed city we had seen yet, it is natural, of course it is natural to speak of one's roof, roofs are in a way the most important thing in a house, between four walls, under a roof, and here was a whole spread out city without a roof. There was the cathedral but it looked very fragile as if you pushed it hard with your finger your finger either would go through it or it would fall over. [Life, 56]

But Stein maintains her own integrity, her distinction from the editorial point of view, simply by recording her observations in her own style--a style that continues to demonstrate how tentative is the act of witnessing, how little we can harvest from our gleaning of the world. With the victory of the Allies comes an endless string of documentary accounts and photographs and films that promise to bring us closer to the facts of the war in Europe. Stein is a cautious, canny member of this documentary assembly. The photograph that introduces her article weirdly illustrates the questions, at once visual and ethical, raised by much of her writing about the war ( 1). How much does this witness see? How much does she know about the surrounding world, and how fully does she respond to that world? Stein and Toklas "see the Rhine," the picture's caption assures us, but due to an accident of lighting, we see not the view from a window but a framed, black square. The image provides an unsettling introduction to a piece built around observations of a foreign country. In a furious response to the predominantly unperturbed tone of Wars I Have Seen, a reviewer in The New York Times wonders, "Didn't Miss Stein ever see the harried, beaten, ragged refugees in Paris from 1933 on? . . . Where are Miss Stein's eyes, those eyes that can so unerringly discern the value of a Picasso?" 34 It is precisely these canny aesthete's eyes, however, through which Life proposes we glimpse Germany. Reinforcing in the strongest imaginable terms a divide between the terrifying world of men in destructive action and these two older women who have given their lives to art and to a sheltered, somewhat unorthodox but fundamentally bourgeois domesticity, this article presents us with a deliberate respite from anguished journalism. In its place we are given a small collection of impressions and disarmingly direct commentary on the causes of and antidotes to war from one of the very first postwar tourists in Germany. Stein herself comes to understand her unique status shortly after her arrival in Frankfurt, as she discovers the Germans looking not at the American soldiers but at "Miss Toklas and myself":

First I was puzzled and then I realized that we were probably the very first ordinary civilian women with American soldiers, not looking official, just looking like American women . . . and [the Germans] realized for the first time that there were going to be thousands of civilians coming there just to look as we were looking. [Life, 54]

And while she is "looking," her special abilities as a collector of art are by no means to be replaced by more predictable capacities for moral outrage. Her aesthetic judgments are exactly what Life requires:

we soon came to the house where Göring's works of art were temporarily housed. . . . It was exciting to see all those pictures but it had nothing to do with Göring, there was no personal taste, he had excellent advice apparently. [Life, 56]

In an eerie, war-inflected reprise of her return to Oakland in April 1935, when she found "no there there," the central purpose of Stein's trip to Germany is to discover emptiness, to find no record of titanic personalities, to see only surfaces and hollow shells of bombed-out buildings, to take a tour, yes, but to find virtually nothing on the trip. 35

Modris Eksteins has recently published an essay on war tourism, focusing primarily on tour guides and accounts of travel after the First World War. Eksteins documents the phenomenon of postwar tourists and tour promoters, arguing that "the sight of civilization in ruin produces . . . an interesting mix of piety and titillation, of rumination and excitement." 36 Stein's quick trip to Germany cannot offer such sublime and suspect emotional satisfactions, since she finds little in the faculty of memory worth attending to--of what use, then, would ruins be? Whatever titillating horror this journey does have to offer must come when Stein reaches her journey's destination--Hitler's mountain retreat in the Alpine town of Berchtesgaden. 37 The photograph of her in this spot comes at the close of the Life essay ( 2). To understand this photograph and the account Stein gives of the occasion it commemorates, we should remember that, in 1945, there were a number of senior Allied officers and intelligence staff who feared that Hitler and his remaining followers would make a last, bloody stand in the "Mountain Redout" of Berchtesgaden. The town and Hitler's sanctuary had become saturated, in the imaginations of soldiers and civilians, with the horrors of the Third Reich.

It is the aura of this place that allows Stein her metonymic description of the next stage of her journey: "off we went to Hitler" (Life, 57). But those five words, which ring with the declarative simplicity of a nightmare, introduce us instead to the most surprising scene of whimsy:

there we were in that big window where Hitler dominated the world a bunch of GIs just gay and happy. It really was the first time I saw our boys really gay and careless, really forgetting their burdens and just being foolish kids, climbing up and around and on top, while Miss Toklas and I sat comfortably and at home on garden chairs on Hitler's balcony. It was funny it was completely funny, it was more than funny it was absurd and yet so natural. [Ibid.]

Stein's long-famous simplicity of diction now serves as a measure of the Allied victory. So completely has Hitler been defeated that where he once ruled soldiers can become children again, and aging women find ordinary comfort. The prepositions, "up and around and on top," speak of liberation and the license to be in places formerly forbidden, places grown-ups aren't usually allowed to go. Stein cannot avoid calling attention to the wonder of this scene--Mother Goose and her gay charges in the now-domesticated heart of darkness--"it was more than funny it was absurd."

This self-consciousness becomes literally manifest in the moment we see frozen in the photograph. As though the pressure of absurdity strikes the whole company simultaneously, Stein reports that "we all got together and pointed as Hitler had pointed" (Life, 57). Their collective pose not only mimes the commanding gesture Hitler might have made as he surveyed his country (and, by implication, the world far beyond his field of vision). The angle of their raised arms and outstretched hands also suggests the Sieg Heil salute itself--one of the most powerfully iconographic gestures of the past century--now turned into the merest assumption of an attitude. As Gallagher points out, this gesture displays "an impulse toward mimetic and iconographic outrage," but she adds that "Stein allies herself visually not only with the victorious American soldiers but also with the stance of victory itself," and thus "the female observer's vision is effectively absorbed into the trajectory of the military gaze." 38 I suggest that Stein by no means fits so easily into the soldiers' company, much as she takes pleasure in horsing around with them in the photograph. Her very next gesture sets her apart again, as she continues to skew the signs of war in the souvenir hunting that follows this anti-salute:

What I wanted was a radiator, Hitler did have splendid radiators, and there was one all alone which nobody seemed to notice, but a radiator a large radiator, what could I do with it, they asked put it on a terrace and grow flowers over it, I said. [Life, 57]

The elegiac associations that might cluster around these future flowers are largely negated by the strikingly odd choice of an object for them to adorn. A radiator remains, however, just the thing that the author of Tender Buttons might be expected to try to carry away from this place. But it is not June of 1914, not the summer when Tender Buttons made its fairly muted debut on the stage of the avant-garde. This short excursion in Life, undertaken in a profoundly different time, before millions rather than hundreds of readers, depends for its success on Stein managing to retain her identity as a famously incomprehensible artist, while also giving a convincing performance as an unremarkable, middle-class American tourist. The critical, satirical edge to the piece--evident in the poses Stein assumes before the Germans and the GIs alike--derives primarily from the odd fact that these two identities exist together in this one radical, ordinary woman.

Near the end of her essay, when she and Alice Toklas are flying back to France with the GIs, Stein comments wryly on her plane's new cargo:

the boys showed us all the things they had acquired. Where they had acquired, what they had acquired, better not know. There are three million American soldiers there and each one of them has to have at least six souvenirs. Dear me. They call these objects liberated. This is a liberated camera. Liberated they are. [Life, 58]

As is the case in all her writings about American soldiers, Stein is entranced by the GI's English usage, the way her native language is changing under the pressures of war. For the victors, "liberated" is a humorously dishonest word, a euphemism, an adjective that evades an ugly truth about the spoils of victory. It is a word that exemplifies and characterizes Stein's lifelong project to shake words loose from their referents, to pry words apart from things. Like "exciting and peaceful" in Paris France, or dozens of other words and moments in this body of her writing, "liberated" belongs in Stein's lexicon of words that reference wartime while also refusing to be only about the war. Helen Button might cry at the end of this piece too, in spite of its cheeriness, since it gives us so little to hold on to. It liberates its readers, finally, from a world that is too strange, too filled with the evidence of past trauma but without the cause and effect, the inquiry into motivation that might make that trauma fit into an explanatory narrative. We see Stein in the photograph from Berchtesgaden liberating a sign associated with Hitler. 39 Whether this liberation is successful we will have to determine for ourselves. While the meanings of that sign may ultimately be as resistant to moving as Hitler's radiators, Stein is conducting an experiment, in the image and the prose she attaches to that image, to determine how far a public moment and an historical gesture can be dislocated. Gallagher, writing about this photograph in particular, and about Stein's post-liberation point of view, finds that "the image is a visual representation of the 'liberation' of Gertrude Stein from a set of wartime political loyalties and representations riven by contradictions, doubts, ambivalences, and from the continual deferral of political interpretation of visual and other evidence." 40 But for Stein, victory does not bring unambiguous clarity, reassertions of meaning, an end to confusions and problems of reference. It brings only the unsettling facts of liberation.

The End of Difference: "Reflection on the Atomic Bomb"

"Off We All Went to See Germany" appeared in Life on 6 August 1945, the day that the United States dropped the atom bomb on Hiroshima. This coincidence serves as well as any single event might to characterize the state of the world that receives Stein's work. Photographs of the devastation in Japan will appear within two weeks in Life. 41 It is difficult to find a newspaper or magazine published in the United States in the years immediately following the end of the Second World War that does not run a series of essays on the meanings of having entered what is already being called the "atomic age." Stein dies on 27 July 1946, but shortly before her death she, too, privately joins this conversation about the Bomb, with a three-paragraph essay, "Reflection on the Atomic Bomb," published in December of 1947 in the Yale Poetry Review. The editors give the piece its title and a gloss: "This is the very last piece that Miss Stein wrote before her death in 1946." 42 It is quintessential Stein:

They asked me what I thought of the atomic bomb. I said I had not been able to take any interest in it.

I like to read detective and mystery stories, I never get enough of them but whenever one of them is or was about death rays and atomic bombs I never could read them. What is the use, if they are really as destructive as all that there is nothing left and if there is nothing there is nobody to be interested and nothing to be interested about. 43

Romanticism and its sociopolitical agent, war, find their apotheosis and their conclusion in this new invention--so completely destructive that it lacks meaning. With her phrase "what is the use," she signals the collapse of the poles of her art: poetry and history, pure and instrumental language, private and public worlds. One cannot measure difference or weigh winner and loser when there is "nothing left." Who can discern dichotomies in this obliteration? Who will there be to recognize this next form of the modern composition, she wonders: "Sure it will destroy and kill a lot, but it's the living that are interesting not the way of killing them, because if there were not a lot left living how could there be any interest in destruction." There are, of course, two enormous "lots" of "living" who would have taken issue with Stein's assessment, however philosophically apt we might find it from our own temporal distance: the wounded, dying, and defeated Japanese and the enormously relieved Americans who had been granted a reprieve from the nightmares of island invasions.

But Stein herself realizes that, in the wake of this second world war, she has very little to say. It is essentially a problem of scale, of calibrating words and things. If the Great War, with its ten million dead, brought us into modernity, what do the fifty million dead in its sequel bring? Why should she continue her demanding, risky search for an appropriate register in which to write about this new form of modernity? The history of her own art ends not with Hitler after all, but with Harry Truman and the invention he authorizes for use. Her last reflection on writing is almost as simple as saying nothing. Here is the whole of her final paragraph:

Everybody gets so much information all day long that they lose their common sense.
They listen so much that they forget to be natural. This is a nice story.

Three weeks before his own death in 1939, W. B. Yeats wrote to Lady Elizabeth Pelham, "Man can embody truth but he cannot know it. . . . You can refute Hegel but not the Saint or the Song of Sixpence." 44 Stein was probably not aware that she had cancer when she wrote her final sentence, and had she lived she would no doubt have found a way to continue using language. And yet this paragraph stands as an end of writing, not a beginning. Like the patient farmers in Paris France, like Yeats in his final days, Stein imagines living in a way that renders words as incidental as the weather. There are no winners and no losers. Only the simplest forms of narrative, the least ambitious kinds of naming (if the fraught activity of naming is even necessary at all), and the last liberation offered by nature.

 

John Whittier-Ferguson is Associate Professor of English at the University of Michigan. He is currently working on a book about World War II and modern memory, with particular focus on the war writings of Gertrude Stein.

Notes

1. Gertrude Stein, Paris France (New York: Livewright, 1970), 63; hereafter abbreviated as PF. The spelling of Bismarck's name, without the "c," is Stein's. I wish to thank here Daniel McKenna, a graduate student at the University of Michigan, for discovering and tracking down a great deal of the periodical literature I discuss in this essay. I am also deeply indebted to my colleagues at the University of Michigan--particularly Kerry Larson, John Kucich, Tobin Siebers, Valerie Traub, Susan Scott Parrish, Carla Mazzio, Michael Schoenfeldt, George Bornstein, and Marjorie Levinson--for helping me with this essay. I have been fortunate, too, in receiving help from my colleagues in the Military Studies Seminar, under the direction of Jonathan Marwil.

2. For a discussion of the publication of Paris France, see A Gertrude Stein Companion: Content with Example, ed. Bruce Kellner (New York: Greenwood Press, 1988), 54.

3. I do not attend to Stein's work around and about World War I, though Vincent Sherry, in a forthcoming book on modernism and the Great War, makes a convincing case for the importance of that war to Stein's mature understanding of language. One of the best recent discussions of the politics of Stein's wartime texts is by Phoebe Stein Davis, "Even Cake Gets to Have Another Meaning," Modern Fiction Studies 44, no. 3 : 568-607.

4. I have written elsewhere on Mrs. Reynolds, which I consider in many ways Stein's most complex text about World War II. See "Stein in Time: History, Manuscripts, Memory," 6, no. 1 : 115-51.

5. Wanda Van Dusen's essay, "Portrait of a National Fetish: Gertrude Stein's 'Introduction to the Speeches of Maréchal Pétain' ," lies as a provocation for a great many of the recent discussions of Stein's politics. Her essay appeared in 3, no. 3 : 69-92. Stein's "Introduction to the Speeches of Maréchal Pétain" appears in the same issue, following Van Dusen's essay. I discuss Van Dusen's essay, and Stein's "Introduction" in my "Stein in Time." Another foundational text for the study of Stein and the war is Jean Gallagher's The World Wars Through the Female Gaze (Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press, 1998).

6. Ulla E. Dydo, from her introductory notes to "Composition as Explanation," in A Stein Reader, ed. Ulla E. Dydo (Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press, 1993), 494; hereafter abbreviated as "CE." I do not find this argument convincing because in her various public utterances Stein does not seem much concerned with a "generation gap" (witness her Lectures in America--a great many of them given to University audiences--which do not show concerns about such a "gap"; think too about her various prolonged exchanges in both World Wars with soldiers, with whom she clearly felt unusually comfortable.) Speaking to the young does not seem to have posed particular problems for Stein. Nor is Dydo entirely clear as to how bringing up the subject of war will make Stein fit more easily with her audience (Dydo makes a passing reference to a "post World War I audience, including some veterans"). Surely, insofar as the war was on the minds of Stein's young listeners (veterans would not have been students in 1926), nothing in contemporary English intellectual culture would have suggested the waste and horrors of World War I as a likely re for cultural progress. The ironies of invoking an English "victory" to Oxbridge undergraduates would have been overwhelming by the mid-1920s. It does Stein a disservice to assume, as Dydo does, that she would not recognize these ironies, building this portion of her essay around the analogy: "As one who has won the battle for the new, she speaks to those who have won on the battlefield." (ibid.).

7. Gertrude Stein, The Geographical History of America, Or The Relation of Human Nature to the Human Mind, introd. William Gass (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins Press, 1973). The Geographical History of America was first published in 1936, and it clearly belongs with the Lectures in America as a consideration of the relations between place and writing, engagement with and freedom from the world, the "human nature and the human mind," to use her terms. See William Gass's introduction to The Geographical History. See also the essay on related concepts in Stein by Nancy Blake, "Everybody's Autobiography: Identity and Absence," Recherches Anglaises et Américaines 15 : 135-45. The strongest discussion of the philosophy of identity as Stein explores it in her Lectures in America is by Jennifer Ashton, "Gertrude Stein for Anyone," ELH 64, no. 1 : 289-331.

8. I base my general sketch of Stein's audience largely on my reading in newspapers of a good many accounts of her lecture tour. Many articles on her appearances around the country devote significant space to describing the attending audience. Clearly, in 1934-5, it was a social coup merely to be seen at a Stein lecture. See, for some examples, "Reporter Tells in Stein Style the Stein Style," Chicago Daily Tribune, 25 October 1934, 17; "Gertrude Stein Arrives and Baffles Reporters by Making Herself Clear," New York Times, 25 October 1934, 25; "Gertrude Stein: Her Words 'Do Get Under Their Skin'," Newsweek, 4, no. 24 (27 October 1934), 24; "Miss Stein Speaks Today to Bewildered 500," New York Times, 2 November 1934, 25; "Princeton Dazed by Gertrude Stein," New York Times, 6 November 1934, 23; "American Opera Luncheon Today," Chicago Tribune, 6 November 1934, 17; "Audience Eyes a Simple Gown at Stein Opera," Chicago Tribune, 8 November 1934, 19; "English Letters to Flower Next in U.S.: Gertrude Stein," Chicago Tribune, 26 November 1934, 4; "Gertrude Stein Comes Home," The New Republic 81 (5 December 1934), 100. Good discussions of Stein's tour are Bryce Conrad's, "Gertrude Stein in the American Marketplace," Journal of Modern Literature 19, no. 2 : 215-33; Robert M. Post's, "'An Audience is an Audience': Gertrude Stein Addresses the Five Hundred," The Kentucky Review 13, no. 1/2 : 71-83; and Anne Herrmann's chapter on Stein in Queering the Moderns: Poses/ Portraits/ Performance (New York: Palgrave, 2000).

9. For a germane discussion of American isolationism, see Piers Brendon, The Dark Valley: A Panorama of the 1930s (New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2000), ch. 20.

10. For discussions of Stein's fears of publicity following the publication of The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas, see first Stein's own account of her crisis, "And Now," from Vanity Fair, (September 1934), reprinted in Vanity Fair: Selections from America's Most Memorable Magazine: A Cavalcade of the 1920s and 1930s, ed. Cleveland Amory and Frederic Bradlee (New York: The Viking Press, 1960): 280-1. See also Richard Bridgman, Gertrude Stein in Pieces (New York: Oxford University Press, 1970), 235. See also the essay by Robert Post, cited above, "Gertrude Stein Addresses the Five Hundred"; and Catherine N. Parke, "'Simple Through Complication': Gertrude Stein Thinking," American Literature 60, no. 4 : 554-74.

11. Gertrude Stein, Writings: 1932-1946 (New York: Library of America, 1998), 222; hereafter abbreviated as GS, II.

12. Gertrude Stein, Everybody's Autobiography (Cambridge, Mass.: Exact Change, 1993).

13. Reading the newspaper accounts of her tour quickly demonstrates how minutely and how searchingly Stein was scrutinized. Everything--her clothing, her mannerisms, her texts, her psyche--is fair game for journalists, who often find themselves more comfortable talking about Stein than about the details of her lectures.

14. Her wartime writing is read in France and England as well, but it is most often directed primarily toward American readers, and when it is published in periodicals, those periodicals are American. The important exception to this generalization is Paris France which, in its conclusion, calls explicitly upon England to intervene in the plight of Europe (recall that this book was first published in England). It is important to note, too, that this writing is comparatively widely circulated and read. Stein makes money writing for The Atlantic or Life that she could not make in more exclusive periodical territory. Her second bestseller in the United States, after the Autobiography, is Wars I Have Seen. Davis, "Even Cake," 592.

15. (PF, 65). Elsewhere in Paris France, Stein characterizes the French themselves as taking comfort from language itself: "The French do love to say a thing and say it completely. That is the reason that once a thing is completely named it does no longer worry them. Now the word une guerre des nerfs, has become a part of their speech, it has no longer any effect upon their nerves. That is their logic fashion and civilisation" .

16. See, for an example, the letter from an angry reader of "The Winner Loses" in The Atlantic: "[T]he Germans ought to pay her top propagandist wages for her passivist view that whatever is is best so long as she can continue to get meat, butter, a little gasoline--and substantial checks in dollars from American publishers. Her bland assumption that 'the winner loses,' even in stricken France under the Nazi heel, represents a view that for sheer stupid optimism reaches a new low for Atlantic's pages. She says too little--too, too little--of what the loser loses at the hands of ruthless Germany. (See news reports in the daily papers. . . .)" (Carlton Wells, Letter to the Editor, The Atlantic 166, no. 6 (December 1940). Soldiers occasionally write to the editor following any of her periodical publications during the war. Though some object to various assertions she makes, a roughly equal number praise her work.

17. An extensive discussion of the problems of narrative shape and the experience of trauma may be found in Lawrence Langer, Holocaust Testimonies: The Ruins of Memory (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1991). The essays collected in the anthology, Tense Past: Cultural Essays in Trauma and Memory, ed. Paul Antze and Michael Lambek (New York: Routledge, 1996), are also important. Two crucial studies of writing and World War I are Paul Fussell's The Great War and Modern Memory (New York: Oxford University Press, 1975), and Samuel Hynes's A War Imagined: The First World War and English Culture (New York: Atheneum, 1991). And for an utterly different, down-to-earth account of attempting to describe untellable moments in war, compare E. B. Sledge's With the Old Breed at Peleliu and Okinawa (New York: Oxford University Press, 1981); or perhaps the most well-known example from the Vietnam War, Tim O'Brien's, "How to Tell a True War Story," in The Things They Carried (New York: Penguin, 1990).

18. For discussions of France in World War II, see Phillip Burrin, France Under the Germans: Collaboration and Compromise (New York: New Press, 1966). See also Ernest R. May, Strange Victory: Hitler's Conquest of France (New York: Hill and Wang, 2000), and Piers Brendon, The Dark Valley, ch. 23. Also see the documentary film on occupied France, The Sorrow and the Pity. Director Marcel Ophuls made this documentary in 1971. The film was originally banned from French television; it shattered the myth of a united French front against the Nazis, showing French people to be much more complexly motivated (as Stein describes them in Paris France and "The Winner Loses") and often to hold a more resigned attitude toward their occupiers than the postwar mythologies would have us believe. I have benefited from Richard Golsan's discussion of the issues surrounding the French national memory of the Vichy years, "History and the 'Duty to Memory' in Postwar France: The Pitfalls of an Ethics of Remembrance," in What Happens to History: The Renewal of Ethics in Contemporary Thought, ed. Howard Marchitello (New York: Routledge, 2001). See also Bertram M. Gordon, Collaboration in France During the Second World War (Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1980). Discussions of Paris France that have helped me in my reading are Zofia Lesinska, "Gertrude Stein's War Autobiographies: Reception, History, and Dialogue," LIT: Literature Interpretation Theory 9, no. 4 : 313-42; Shirley Swartz, "The Autobiography as Generic 'Continuous Present': Paris France and Wars I Have Seen," English Studies in Canada 4, no. 2 : 224-37. See also the more general discussion of Stein's war writings, Maria Diedrich, "'A Book in Translation about Eggs and Butter': Gertrude Stein and World War II," in Women and War: The Changing Status of American Women from the 1930s to the 1950s, ed. Maria Diedrich and Dorothea Fischer-Hornung (New York: Berg, 1990).

19. Stein gives us a glimpse of the lack of information on the radio in a wry passage connecting war and music: "war naturally does make music but certainly this war with everybody really everybody listening to the radio, there is nothing but music" (PF, 38).

20. "In Memory of W. B. Yeats," in W. H. Auden, Collected Poems, ed. Edward Mendelson (New York: Vintage Books, 1991). Mendelson gives the date of composition as February, 1939 .

21. The most important text by Stein discussing her understanding of genius is "What are Master-pieces and Why Are There so Few of Them," in Gertrude Stein, Writings: 1932-1946. Her The Geographical History of America is also crucial on this subject. The most extensive discussion of Stein and genius may be found in Bob Perelman, The Trouble with Genius: Reading Pound, Joyce, Stein, and Zukofsky (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1994). For important background on the origins of the modern idea of genius, see the discussion of Proust in Richard Terdiman, Present Past: Modernity and the Memory Crisis (Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press, 1993).

22. Stein and Alice Toklas, after a frantic 36 hours in Paris in 1939, where they gather papers, clothes, and a few paintings from their quarters at 27, rue de Fleurus, spend the war in the Département of the Ain, in Southeastern France, living first in the little town of Bilignin and then, when their lease is cancelled in 1943, moving to the nearby town of Culoz until the end of the war. They return to Paris in December of 1944.

23. This resemblance has been most famously and cruelly discussed by Wyndham Lewis in his chapters on Stein in Time and Western Man; it had become a commonplace by the 1930s, repeated often, for example, in reviews of her lectures in America. It is also invoked usefully by Ben Ray Redman in a piece that appeared in The Saturday Review, praising Wars I Have Seen. Redman concludes "The Importance of Being Earnest," his essay on Stein's memoir, by saying that Stein dares to be "as simple as a child, pointing straight, going straight to the heart of a subject, to its roots; pointing straight, when and where adults would take a fancier way than pointing, because they had not learned to point." The Saturday Review 28, no. 10 (10 March 1945), 30.

24. Gertrude Stein, Tender Buttons (Los Angeles: Sun and Moon Press, n.d.), 9.

25. Stein wrote this "Helen Button" section of Paris France some time before beginning Paris France itself (and before "war time" had literally commenced). As with so much of Stein's ostensibly autobiographical writing, this fact complicates any understanding we might have entertained about this narrative as a record, a witnessing of events (see Bridgman, Stein in Pieces, 298 and note).

26. This scene is particularly terrifying in the context of Stein's work, since through the mid- and late-1930s she has used the phrase from the nursery rhyme, "I am I because my little dog knows me," as a focal point for thinking about the problems of identity. Now, the tables turned, Helen does not know a supposedly familiar dog who seems, also, not to know her.

27. In her own wartime reading, Stein regularly returned to the prophecies of a "Leonardo Blake." I discuss his work and the importance of prophecy to Stein in the context of my presentation of Mrs. Reynolds in "Stein in Time."

28. Gallagher, World Wars, 144.

29. Some examples: "The Liberation of Gertrude Stein," Life 17 (2 October 1944), 83-4; "Gertie and the G.I.s," Time 45, no. 16 (16 April 1945), 26-7; see also a mention in the "People" section of Time 44, no. 11 (11 September 1944), 48. Her postwar portrait of U.S. soldiers, Brewsie and Willie, receives a number of notices. See "A GI is a GI is a . . . ," Newsweek 3, 4 (3 September 1945), 30; and "GI Novel Written By Gertrude Stein," New York Times, 25 August 1945, 13. See also the later account, by Frank Gervasi, of finding Stein in France after the war's end, "The Liberation of Gertrude Stein," Saturday Review 54, 34 (21 August 1971), 13. Gervasi also has an essay in Life, "The Liberation of Gertrude Stein," Life, 17 (2 October 1944), 83-4.

30. The text of this broadcast is reproduced in Eric Sevareid's Not So Wild a Dream (New York, A. A. Knopf, 1946), 461-2. Sevareid also describes in some detail his "liberation" of Stein in Culoz in this book (457-62).

31. See the account in John Malcolm Brinnin, The Third Rose: Gertrude Stein and Her World (Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley, 1987), 378-84. An account of her trip to Germany with the 441st Troup Carrier Group may be found in Brinnin on pages 392-4. See also the photographs from this trip (not the same as the ones published in Life) in Gertrude Stein in Words and Pictures, ed. Renate Stendhal (Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books, 1994), 246-54.

32. I have not been able to locate this film; it is referenced in the caption to a photograph of the film being made, in Stein in Words and Pictures, 254. Attached to the photograph is a note from the Associated Press, saying that the film was made for "A U.S. Army Information and Education Course."

33. Gertrude Stein, "Off We All Went to See Germany," Life 19 (6 August 1945): 54-58; hereafter abbreviated as "Life." The soldiers in charge of Stein and Alice Toklas's trip to Germany were part of the 9th Army Air Force. The 441st Troop Carrier Group was part of the 50th Troop Carrier Wing in the IXth troop carrier command. The Army Air Forces In World War II, vol. 3, ed. Wesley Frank Craven and James Lea Cate (Chicago: Chicago University Press, 1951), 113-4.

34. Libby Benedict, "The Disillusionment That Calls Itself Objectivity," The New York Times Book Review (20 May 1945): 4.

35. Stein, Everybody's Autobiography, 298.

36. Modris Eksteins, "War, Memory, and the Modern: Pilgrimage and Tourism to the Western Front," in World War I and the Cultures of Modernity, ed. Douglas Mackman and Michael Mayes (Jackson: University Press of Mississippi, 2000), 153.

37. Hitler had a villa at Berchtesgaden and a retreat--the "Adlerhorst"--above the town as well. The photographs accompanying the Life piece show Stein on the balcony of the villa, not at the "Eagle's Nest."

38. Gallagher, World Wars, 146, 147, 148.

39. A more contemporary experiment that bears comparison with Stein's gesture here is the Occupations series of Anselm Kiefer, the German artist who had photographs of himself taken giving the Nazi salute in various culturally resonant sites in Europe (the Coliseum in Rome, for example). See the discussion of his work by Matthew Biro, Anselm Kiefer and the Philosophy of Martin Heidegger (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1998). See also the chapter on Kiefer's work in Andreas Huyssen, Twilight Memories: Marking Time in a Culture of Amnesia (New York: Routledge, 1995), ch. 11.

40. Gallagher, World Wars, 148.

41. "The War Ends: Burst of Atomic Bomb Brings Swift Surrender of Japanese," Life 19, no. 8 (20 August 1945), 25.

42. Yale Poetry Review, no. 7 , 3. The editors of this short-lived journal are Rolfe Fjelde, Thomas McMahon, and Harvey Shapiro. They take the essay from the Yale archive, with the permission of Carl Van Vechten. There is no evidence that Stein wrote the essay for this journal, and the "they" in her opening sentence is thus somewhat mystifying in its reference. I read it as her expression of a general sense of the widespread asking of questions about the Bomb. Presumably the Review's editors received the information that the essay was Stein's last completed work from Van Vechten. Richard Bridgman calls it her "last composition" (Stein in Pieces, 339 n). The editors of the Library of America Writings also cite this as her "last piece of writing" (GS, II, 840).

43. Gertrude Stein, "Reflection on the Atomic Bomb" (GS, II, 823) (New York: Library of America, 1998), 823. All citations from this brief essay come from this single page in Stein's Writings.

44. The Letters of W. B. Yeats, ed. Allan Wade (London: Rupert Hart-Davis, 1954), 922.

8.3 389-403

[Access article in PDF]

Appreciation, Depreciation: Modernism's Speculative Bubble

Jennifer Wicke

What follows is a position paper, although it contains a number of modernist specimen cases upon which, as if they were park benches, it comes momentarily to rest. In the early pages of Ludwig Wittgenstein's Philosophical Investigations, itself a modernist test case of sorts, Wittgenstein proposes a language game consisting of a single word--"slab"--shouted out as bricklayers build a foundation and a house of language. 1 Think of this essay as akin to the slab game, a somewhat deliberately crude attempt to set up a way of talking about the larger foundation of our enterprise as critics of modernism and modernity, instead of an elegant perambulation within modernist textual spaces. Skirting the perimeter of modernism's walls, my polemic addresses the critical superstructure surrounding modernism's revival, probing its brickwork and sounding its slabs. These slabs, serving as the park benches I invoked above, are different in kind; one is a material conceit coming from the ground literally, while the second offers a critical concept taken from Ernst Bloch as a metonymic bench. Interspersed are leaves drawn from several modernist artifacts, while the entire essay rests on economic metaphors from speculative finance. Bubbles and slabs are antithetical, yet both can refer to critical discourse, in the first case as a speculative investment in value, in the second (slabs) as an antifoundationalist foundation for critical practice.

I'll trace out a conceit through much of the argument, borrowing an analogy from another cultural arena also subject to speculative bubbles. "I speak," to cite Miss Prism in TheImportance of Being Earnest, "horticulturally." Consider the following remark, on its face yet another frenzied, fin-de-siécle denunciation of alterity: "It is impossible to deny that the blending of foreign blood has seriously impaired the value of the pure strains. Many of the continental sorts lack cleanliness and when they crop up amongst their purer sisters their appearance at once betrays them." We imagine we know the discourse of empire, with its binaries of contamination and purity, self and other, so well we could gloss this in our sleep. Yet the excoriation of sordid miscegenation with pure native stock emerges not from imperial apologetics, nor from the popular press, but from a troubled report put out by the beleaguered British tulip growers association, circa 1900. The once majestic Royal National Tulip Society, representing the aesthetic and taxonomic elite of the tulip industry, a society which was down to two members when it tried to confer its varietal prizes in 1926, makes an eerie parallel to the fates and fortunes of the modernist critical industry. 2 The Royal National Tulip Society--which waned altogether in 1936--had been the arbiter of excellence in all things tulip for centuries, at the forefront of aesthetic and horticultural innovation in the United Kingdom; and had an eclectic membership made up of hobbyists, botanists, aristocratic gardeners, and garden-variety tulip fanciers (TT, 247). The creations of the Society, given the name "English Florist's tulips," sprang up as one-of-a-kind marvels in country estate gardens as well as in humble plots cultivated by the side of the railways. Again for centuries, English Florist's tulips were judged semiannually in well-attended meetings held by convention in public houses. There individual tulips, among them the feathered Bizarre, "George Hayward," the soft, yellow "Mrs. Moon," the resplendent "Bronze King," and the Bybloemen tulip, "Princess Charlotte's Cenotaph," went head-to-head for prizes and approbation, their decapitated petaled tresses uniformly inserted into three-inch-tall brown beer bottles.

What had interfered with this long reign of horticultural glory, not to say purity? In a sense mass culture was the villain, the same foe slinking down the pike and gunning for modern(ist) literature and the arts, at least in commonly-held versions of modernism. The first insidious notion capable of shaking the foundation of the Royal National Tulip Society's authority came, not surprisingly, from the United States, that bastion of sleazy mass culture. In the early-nineteenth century an American gardener had planted and raised tulips en masse as bedding plants; the discovery failed to catch on commercially at that juncture, but at the turn of the century Dutch tulip entrepreneurs--who had a long history of making guilders off the backs of tulips--systematized and mass-marketed the American tulip bed invention. The resulting bed or plot of tulips became not only mass culture, but mass spectacle. The pivotal World Exposition held in Paris in 1889, itself a design monument to modernity, where the Eiffel Tower was erected as sheer public spectacle, introduced the first world exhibition of massed tulips as spectacular eye candy. The great Dutch tulipiere, E. H. Krelage, filled the beds of the Trocadero Palace during the fair with what a current newspaper editorial disparagingly called the "bang in the eye" of thousands of planted tulips (TT, 223). Tulips en masse surrounded the base of the iconic apex of modern urbanism, adding a horizontal, floral modernism to the Eiffel Tower's vertical modernist spectacle.

The mass cultural sea of tulips Krelage had planted was comprised of no ordinary or anonymous tulip legions. As another first, these were brand-name tulips, the "Darwin" brand to be exact. Krelage had the creative and marketing genius to buy the rights to the name from Charles Darwin's son, Francis (TT, 259). "Darwin" was an apt new brand-name for a diverse collection of pink and purple tulip bulbs he had bought at a vast tulip close out sale in Flanders, as that region ceased growing tulips commercially (TT, 262). The individual botanical and varietal names of the motley collection were excised; Darwin tulips were collectivist, a brand instead of a taxonomic variety or florist's name for a unique type. Once branded "Darwin," tulips became modern commodities--not because they were being sold and traded on the market, which they had been for centuries before--but because they now were cultivated to be planted en masse, and given a brand name accordingly: tulips became a modern, or even modernist, floral genre--tulips had truly evolved.

Subsequent to Krelage's breakthrough on the tulip branding front, tulips also entered modernity as a pivot of the modernizing tourist industry. In order to replenish consumer wonderment at the spectacle of tulip fields in bloom, thousands of bulbs were given away as municipal marks of esteem, as awards for heroism, and even in exchange for arms at the outset of World Wars I and II (TT, 268). Tulips shared another feature of modernism in their internationalism and cosmopolitanism. An international floral currency, the tulip began to be grown commercially in far-flung places, such as Japan in the 1920s. The Japanese deplored tulips as unrefined and vulgar, but overcame these aesthetic objections since they had the ideal climatic conditions for their cultivation and export to less-refined, tulip-hungry Western nations (TT, 268). Tulips acted as the thin edge of the economic wedge in complex colonial situations, at times valuable as a raw material for "extraction," at other moments important as a symbolic show of imperial floral might. Hardball economic battles waged by Britain over its possession and control of colonial tulip bulbs echoed the violent, and ultimately successful, mid-nineteenth-century struggles of the British empire to wipe out the indigenous Indian textile industry. British women's clothing transmuted the often bloody suppression of Indian weaving into flower-strewn calico cloth, its innocuous floral prints masking a secret history; so too did brand-name tulips flower on the foreign, colonial soil whose native tulip bulbs had been confiscated. 3

Perhaps not surprisingly, it was a celebrated Irish gardener, William Robinson, who proposed an anticolonialist twist in modern tulip display. In The Wild Garden, Robinson argues that tulips should be set out in masses, but not in delineated beds (TT, 259). Instead they should be planted in nooks, on hillsides, or across a lawn, where they will appear to have sprung up randomly in the wild. Robinson articulates an anti-Plantation explosion of tulips beyond the pale of the garden plot, and transforms the most cultivated, artificial, and man-made flower in European history into a simulacrum of wildness. Only the modern fashion for a Gustave Le Bon-like crowd of tulips--that is, the brand-name cultivars Krelage and others had taught the masses to see and revel in en masse--makes it possible for a subversive gardener to achieve its antithesis, the aesthetic effect of rogue tulips springing up wildly yet beautifully over a "natural" landscape. Robinson poeticized the crowd of tulips by embracing their previously suppressed wild side, in an act of colonial (Irish) mimicry of the English Florist's tulip so strategic, his tulips could be called Bhabha hybrids avant la lettre. By dint of a speculative bubble afloat on the material froth of history, making a nearly circumferential global orbit, and scattered by economic, aesthetic, and political revolutions alike, the tulip had traced its way back to a faux sauvage fashion identity.

Modernist tulips also parallel modernism by providing a material canvas for extensive aesthetic experimentation--or enough of a parallel to keep this conceit in play. The departure from Kantian formalism in the aesthetic evaluation of tulips was decisive by the end of the nineteenth century. Heretofore, the criteria for excellence in tulips were largely formalist. Dr. W. G. Hardy had written the seminal treatise, "On Perfection of Form in the Tulip," in 1847, wherein he took up the gardening cudgels against those who disagreed that the half-sphere was the perfect form of the tulip blossom (TT, 232-7). Complex mathematical equations subtended the raging arguments regarding the beauty of tulips--whether their beauty inhered most in the straight-on frontal view, or when seen from above looking down into the cup of the tulip, required alternative calculations of sublime mathematical precision; petal depth in relation to diameter offered a Platonic calculus of tulip Form. Modernist tulip genres abandoned all such aesthetic numerology and the formalism beneath it. The great English gardener Gertrude Jekyll began suggesting, as of 1899, that avant-garde gardens contain beds of multiple tulips chosen so that their colors modulated in finely-tuned colorscapes--for example, "the blackish-purple Faust tulip" shifting to a lighter and redder variety, bronzes shading into purple-tipped copper, and flame reds coexisting with crimson in a fauvist riot. 4 With such a colorist's eye, mass tulips could still be differentiated as spectacle; Jekyll's Saussurean langue of tulips insisted that their value was always diacritical, a matter of their relation to the other tulips in the bed. Jekyll and other modern greats of the English garden established a modernist garden practice, eschewing essentialism and "the old stable ego of [tulipine] characters" in favor of fluid, nonlinear, and self-reflexive gardening techniques. 5 Gardens were to be shaped with verbal and visual allusiveness: Jekyll's tulips entered into a modernist compact in which their most prized attributes, their individual characteristics, were set afloat in a collage-iste sea of quotation, reference, and countermemory.

On the other hand, the beauty of modern tulips was also a social construction, contingent on the material context of their viewing. The gleaming radiance of the 30,000 Silver Hawk white tulips displayed in the Sheffield Botanical Garden dazzled spectators thanks to the coal mining strike then in progress; their unbesmirched whiteness was the direct result of lowered smoke in the city's atmosphere, and depending on the political point of view, veritably radiated governmental perfidy or the strength of the labor cause (TT, 271).

The swerve toward massification in outdoor displays of tulips was accompanied by its opposite: the very modernist vogue for tulips displayed indoors as cut flowers, destined for vases and bouquets. Oscar Wilde was among the first writers to bring the cut tulip into his textual mise-en-scène; in The Picture of Dorian Gray, tulips in the drawing room hang their heads over the rim of blue and white porcelain vases from Japan, the visual trope of decadent modernity. 6 The tulip had rarely been contemplated before in its decapitated state, sundered from its invisible bulb, until its bizarreries suddenly made the indoor tulip visible, and au courant. It is almost frightening on this score to search out floral references in Virginia Woolf's Mrs. Dalloway, so profuse and pervasive do they prove to be. 7 Almost every page is rampant with blooms. To inventory them with an eye to tulips requires sharp critical pruning. In film theory a distinction is made when discussing the sound of a film between diegetic sound and the film's score or sound track. Diegetic sound refers to sound or music emanating from something in the scene, such as a song being played on a car radio, while the score or sound track comes from "outside" the scene or narrative, superimposed upon the visual images. Woolf's writing is rife with "diegetic" flowers--characters fill vases, sniff bouquets, peer into garden blossoms, purchase flowers, and sell them--yet flowers, petals, blossoms, gardens are the green fuse that drives her language: sinuous vines and proliferating blossoms are Woolf's primary metonymies. Mrs. Dalloway hypostatizes flowers, and almost obsessively specifies them. Among those mentioned diegetically or as glimmering metonyms are roses of all colors and kinds, including hallucinated red roses on Septimus's wallpaper, dahlias, sweet pea, violets, hollyhocks, lilies, syringa, blue hydrangeas, orchids, pampas grass, purple heather, moss, carnations, lilacs, delphiniums, iris--and one and only one mention of tulips, as follows: "It was her nature to enjoy. . . . She enjoyed practically everything. If you walked with her in Hyde Park now it was a bed of tulips, now a child in a perambulator, now some absurd little drama she made up on the spur of the moment." 8 So Peter Walsh muses about Clarissa's character. The sight of the tulip bed triggers her enjoyment, but provides an occasion for her to illuminate the world for someone else. The tulip bed she gestures towards is a shared visual spectacle that the massified modern tulip synecdochizes perfectly. Even these almost throwaway lines about the tulip bed are significant in a novel so bombarded with the language of flowers, if one pauses for a bit of textual spadework around the flower's edge. One common critical notion about spectacle follows Guy Debord's determinist analysis in The Society of the Spectacle: that is, spectators are in thrall to spectacle, and their thralldom is commodified as an act of consumption. 9 But Mrs. Dalloway as a whole will have none of this fixed economy of the spectacle, which Clarissa and others cut against repeatedly. Clarissa's expressed delight over the sight of the tulips nudges Peter Walsh into a moment's shared reverie. The modernist tulip bed is a commodified spectacle that dissolves and deliquesces with the nudge of an elbow. Like the coin Clarissa throws into the Serpentine in an act of expenditure, so too do tulips work their tiny magic as a feature of her gift economy. Clarissa is too old-fashioned perhaps to have cut tulips in her home, but she tiptoes through the modernist tulips to dapple the sight of them with the wonder of her enthusiasm. Rather than providing an occasion of "shock," which the novel so amply limns as a corollary modern experience, the tulip bed spectacle provides a distraction, in Walter Benjamin's terms, one that in Mrs. Dalloway's gift economy is only a proper distraction when disproportionately shared. 10

Seventeenth-century Tulipomania and the South Sea Bubble affair of the eighteenth century are retrospective instances of speculative frenzy reaching the level of the sublime, or at least the sublimely hysterical; the modernist tulip market I speak of doesn't have the gossamer sublimity of those bubbles, but instead the gritty, embedded materiality of the smutty foam that delineates a port's edge. Tulips no longer waxed and waned in value overnight, nor were single bulbs hoarded as species of gold. Financial speculation is an iridescent bubble in much modern socioeconomic theory, whereby the airy liquidity of intangible speculative value is privileged for its very vulnerability to the surface tensions that cause it to pop--yet one more demonstration of the mysteries of commodity form, and the contradictions of capitalism. 11 Modernism as a cultural icon, or bubble, or iconic bubble, to oxymoronize, does not resemble the feeding frenzy of past Bubbles or manias, when capitalism was in doubt as a world system, nor does it bob up and down in the waters of a singular "market." Bursting modernism's bubble becomes necessary, all the more so when our own frantic critical splashing tries to make one large bubble come to the surface, even if it be a cluster of bubbles with the adjective "new" on its label. That is to say, we as critics and scholars of modernism have to recognize our own resemblance to the Royal National Tulip Society, insofar as we also attempt to keep hold of modernism and retain the right to award retroactive prizes to sportive modernist hybrids. The Royal National Tulip Society clung to its role as arbiter of tulip excellence, as it disavowed massified tulips, brand-name tulips, national and global tulip economies, modern spectacle, and the commercialization of tulip tourism. The parallel disavowals we make in our self-professed roles as arbiters of the new modernisms include purging modernist orthodoxy of formalism, tradition, hierarchies, social Darwinism, commercialism, bourgeois modernism, neo-imperialism, and totalization of all kinds, without seeing how much we rely on the modernist brand.

Modernism is a brand name. Coming from me, I should stress, that's a compliment. Brand names have all the complexity of the Hegelian hieroglyph, and they offer cultural space for the hierophantic, the necrophantic, and ideological ghosts of all kinds. A brand name is not prima facie a shill, a facade covering an empty sameness, a con game designed to persuade gullible consumers that identical items differ in kind due to their brand name. Brand names carve out a locus for social recognition or attention, yet also defy linear logic or cause and effect reasoning. Brand names are exquisitely sensitive diacritical registers; they are more than the sum of their parts, if those parts are taken to mean products, the ads for them, production, distribution, and consumption. Brands can die as persons die, yet unlike the latter, be raised from the dead in their own lifetime. Brands are aesthetic, onto-politico-material agglomerates that live because, as with Tinkerbell, we have applauded them into reanimation. Brand names also can live a crepuscular existence, since twilight sleep or suspended animation is often preferable to expending a brand's waning spirit in a waste of shame--or killing it off. Modernism's brand name, as we know, lingered for decades in such a boring twilight sleep, etherized upon a dissecting table, or slumbering in a jar. Efforts such as the Modernist Studies Association, the "New Modernisms" conferences, and even a provocative journal devoted to , share credit for reawakening a slumbering critical and scholarly and aesthetic spirit--modernism's brand. Each has something to do with resurrecting and refurbishing a brand in advanced moribundity--at least in some parts of the world. And as with so many commercial brands, the modernist brand can only be resurrected by ironizing or implicitly denying its original cultural status. This is glorious and salutary in some ways, but should not be mistaken as gestures of pure cultural exhumation or backdated exoneration. Brand names are revived so that they can still be of use, can still move the goods. In marketing there is a name for this: rebranding. A return to modernism with a difference, and with a plural vengeance, as in "new modernisms," legitimately opens key debates, stages productive re-readings, and enacts agonistic language games of genuine import and ferocity. We cannot ignore, however, our own investments in modernism's speculative bubble. As revivers of its brand, a brand we cannot seem to do without, we re-brand ourselves as critics and theorists just as we rebrand modernist others.

Because these comments can easily be misconstrued as a tired version of the self-critical lament that "we're all complicit," or even worse in my book, that any mode of criticism, interpretation, or theory inevitably "appropriates" or "co-opts" something that doesn't belong to it, I'll harp perhaps unnecessarily on what I don't mean to say, by way of the now highly attenuated tulip analogy. Tulip growers of the late-nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries were not "complicit" with a grubby market in tulips worldwide, nor did they co-opt or appropriate authentic or indigenous qualities of tulips by forcing bulbs, hybridizing them, and finally creating tulip brands. The fierce competition between and among tulip fanciers, tulip state apparatuses, and imperializing tulip stratagems doesn't boil down to hegemonic violence, or not exclusively so. Within a churning roil of bubbles, among them such contingent and overdetermined elements as color intensity, royal patronage systems, the rise of the natural history museum, botany hobby kits, the predilection for British railway supervisors to dabble in passionate gardening, nationalism, internationalism, cosmopolitanism, little Englandism, the transformation of public space in the modern city, Dutch mercantilism, tourism, feminism, diplomacy, imperial competition, the brutal exigencies of colonialism and slave labor, beauty, the Eiffel Tower, and ad infinitum, the agglomerate bubble of the modern tulip market burbles to the surface.

As go tulips, so goes modernism. That is, its meaning is inseparable from its uses and its overdeterminations. A relatively common stance amongst those who would like to "make modernism new" leans away from the so-called "high modernist canon," and tilts toward lesser known or even unknown modernist artists to escape what appears to be the cul-de-sac of high modernism. Exorcising the modernist canon posthumously, these critical acts of purification disregard the modernist branding that, like Sherwin Williams paint, covers everything, even criticism and critique. Those nouveau modernist critics who wish to enlarge the modernist canon, so to speak--and already the terms "modernist" and "canon" and "enlarge" beg too many questions to address here--had better hope that the illusion of a modernist or high modernist canon stays in place, to permit rebranding along the edges of a very big tent.

Another and to me better frame for the reappraisal of modernism I pluck from the resonant, splendid critical opus of Ernst Bloch, resurrecting a term he himself had borrowed, in both cases of borrowing to infuse it anew. In the essays collected together as The Utopian Function of Artand Literature, 12 Bloch cites "colportage," a real word that historically referred to the practice of travelling booksellers who crisscrossed Europe and elsewhere from the sixteenth to the early-twentieth centuries, selling novels, medical tracts, romances, scientific pamphlets, calendars, fairy tales, political documents, sermons, housewifery manuals, adventure tales, pornography, and prayer books at market fairs, from wagons, on the street, or house to house. Colporteurs, then--and the phrase unfortunately has nothing to do whatsoever with Cole Porter--in their meandering commercial travels gathered up, collected, and retailed the chaff and the wheat, the flotsam and the jetsam, the cream and the skim milk of published material of their moment. By means of colportage books and publications that belonged to completely different discourses, market niches, and even ontological levels were thrown together; in their array constituting more than the sum of their inventory. Cheek by jowl, their presence a matter of contingency as much as supply and demand, the colportage stocks taken as a whole offered, via commercial exchanges, an experience of "the Novum, the startlingly and unexpectedly new," (UF, xxxvii).
